author: Slow Hand
content:
As someone who mainlines a *lot* of music on the regular and has been doing so for two decades now let me say that it's a tradeoff. I consider myself to be a fan of music *foremost* and a musician second. Even though I rate being a musician *very* highly. The impulse to make music is secondary to the urge to discover and appreciate it.

Time spent listening to records is time lost doing something else. Whether that's performing music, raising a family, pursuing a career goal, or saving the world. In some senses I think of myself as a very lopsided individual.

Life, in all of it's variety, is too big to get your arms around it all. So don't feel bad about prioritizing certain things to the detriment of other stuff. We can't do it all. Lean into the aspects that you enjoy most and then team up with those who have chosen to specialize in the things that you rank second.

author: chrissorem
content: This made me think of a production technique Ive stumbled on.  We all have our go to instincts that can lead to a similar feeling across a  record.  Generally there is a dominant instrument that the song was written on such as guitar or piano maybe a synth.  Take a filled out productions and mute all the main ingredients and leave the additive colors, only the sprinkles on top. And start rebuilding the production around that. It can take you to an entirely different  universe and provide contrast in the arch of the record

author: BatMeckley
content:
Couple things:
1) no one is actually a perfectionist. It doesn’t exist. I heard a great story of someone telling (I want to say) Richard Marx that he hadn’t released his record yet cause he’s a perfectionist and RM replied “Bullshit. Name one thing you’ve ever done that’s actually perfect. You’re just scared to move on.”  That story has stuck with me.

2) I’m a fairly decent guitar player, have made an actual career of being paid to do it. And I STILL am either constantly hiring people better than I or recording things note by note and then assembled in protools afterwards. Dr Luke might be the best guitarist I’ve ever been around (and I’ve hung with Blake Mills, Tim Pierce, Phil X), and he CONSTANTLY would just hit record, play the four chords of the song free time, and then cut them up and drop them on the ones or wherever they’re supposed to go in the song. My favorite thing about making records vs performing them live is that on record NO ONE CARES how you got there, just that you did. Unless your groove has something particularly magic to offer I’d get over the one take mentality pretty quick.

author: Rollmottle
content:
How to simultaneously operate as if there are no stakes, while being in the chair with real stakes at play? Some questions I ask myself:

Do I instinctively know the tools I have? Do I operate whatever tools I choose as if they’re an extension of myself? Do they disappear? There’s never a question of what do we use here, you just know. You weren’t bound by your tools when you didn’t know them, why would you be bound by them knowing them cold? Embrace and commit to what you have. The new plug-in isn’t going to make you better. 

Am I operating from fear and scarcity? What will my engineer friends think of my snare? What if I release the song and nobody listens? What if I’m not as good as I think I am? What if I don’t get another client? What if I can’t make rent? These can all creep in to make what was once fun and playful, “work.” But you probably didn’t get into this to do “work.” Success is built over time, not whether you fucked the snare tone that one time. Be OK with failure. Embrace it. Then, ask yourself: do you *really* have anything to lose?

Do you know who you are? You’re not Shawn Everett or Jon Castelli or Serban. You’re you. Stop trying to parse what Castelli would do and start knowing what you’re going to do. Run towards your idiosyncrasies. Embrace them. Become undeniably you because I bet whatever you did years ago was unmistakably you.

author: BatMeckley
content:
Someone in the mix channel had mused about what Serbian’s assistant’s do, and it brings me back to “The people that know how will always work for the people that know why”

Do you know the actual reasons why you feel your work doesn’t measure up yet? Hint: it’s very rarely strictly the sonics and/or mix. That Olivia Rodrigo album sounded objectively terrible, but FELT awesome. And that’s what mattered in the end.  Benny Blanco became successful with a folder full of songs at 120 bpm cause he didn’t know how to change the tempo, and stacks of kick drums because he didn’t know how to eq (he just layers a brighter kick on top if it needs more snap). When I’d ask him why he pretty much did anything it was always “I dunno, man, it just sounds cool!”. Make sure you’re attacking the work with that kind of mindset. 

When I get lost in the minutiae I try to zoom out and just be like “does this whole track feel good? Am I instinctually bobbing my head?” And if not, why?

95% of the songs that people have sent me here, the issue hasn’t been their space, or their monitoring, or whether they used a 60s or 70s guitar, or if they mixed analog or in the box. The issues almost always tend to be much less narrow in scope. Make sure you zoom out and just go “is this cool?”

author: oaklandmatt
content:
Oliver power tools and kshmr are the most useful and most modern packs. Not sure what kind of music you're making but for my workflow I like doing whatever I feel on a production and then having quick "modern" drum sounds I can reach for that immediately can put things into the present.

I'm doing a production right now for a UK artist where they gave me a throwback sounding demo, but I know the artist is a young 2023 female pop star. So I did a bunch of organic shit (acoustic through my 67, some live claps, shit like that), then I threw some kshmr and oliver loops in to just see what the hybrid of classic and modern sounds like. Production is basically done now

author: Slow Hand
content: I learned quickly that in musical collaboration there's often little sense in *talking* about whether an idea will work. *Just do it* and then listen to the difference. It will probably be very obvious which one feels better.

author: popaganda.
content: No matter what I’d be trying to build off a live performance. Vocals and guitar at the same time if possible, make sure the artist is comfortable enough to really deliver the way they did on their videos. Sometimes when artists get in the studio they get way in their heads, and then the process of doing takes and dressing up a track piece by piece can really cloud up the original energy that the fans connected with. So no matter how you eventually dress it up, the core has to be as dynamic and connective as possible.

author: NoahNeedleman
content:
@BatMeckley is the resident Grammy Loser on this topic, but I’ve made a decent living doing some indie and major label stuff as a vocal producer. 

Deliverables really depend on the producer you’re working with. In my experience it’s 50/50 whether they want tuned or raw, comped or all the takes- etc. 

The key things that keep me getting called are, in no particular order:

Communication. Everybody knows what to expect and what is to be expected. 

Professionalism. The room is clean, mics are up, lighting is right, session is loaded. 

Intuition. All the artistic/personal things. Making the artist feel safe enough to be dangerous, knowing how hard you can push them to get a take, knowing where the line is between their vision and yours, etc…

Sonics. I want my artists to feel expensive when they’re recording, so getting the mic and cue mix right is everything. 

Speed. A comp up by the time they’re done tracking, a quick shine to make it feel special, and a bounce for them to take with them.

Everything else is on a per session basis. I can deliver a fully mixed/tuned vocal and everything in between, so it all depends on communication ahead of time.

author: BatMeckley
content:
Things that I didn’t work on that blow my mind vocally: When the Circus Comes by Los Lobos. A lot of the 1975 stuff is really really well put together vocally. It’s Not Living if its Not With You is full of incredible vocal tricks. Worth repeated listenings. Youngblood by 5SOS is a modern song really well put together. Think Andrew Watt handled the vocals on that and did a fantastic job getting the take out of Luke. Dance Hall Days by Wang Chung is always a good reference. Mercy Street by Peter Gabriel (the whole SO record) pretty unfuckwithable. Bang Bang is always a great reference because you can really show a singer the difference between a Jessie J and an Arianna. Comes in handy in sessions a lot.

If you’re looking for creative, the whole Dissociatives record is a constant reference. I’d start with “Horror With Eyeballs”

author: popaganda.
content: I’ve been deep-diving on Daniel Johns this last week and really been thinking about the toll that being creative can take on people. It came up yesterday in the VC too. In some ways our culture likes to reward artists being martyrs, but it’s never something to strive for. I think as producers one of the biggest parts of our job is to be a grounding presence and a support for artists who can sometimes have pretty wild swings. But we’re artists too in our own right with our own bipolar tendencies. In a way that can create an empathy bond between us…we can understand the manic exuberance of making an amazing thing and how there’s usually a pendulum swing in the other direction to compensate. But I kind of think our job as producers is to have our shit together enough to buffer that bipolar thing and make a sanctuary where an artist can feel at home. Just my random thought for the day.

author: oaklandmatt
content:
Most things that have been said, I agree with. But I think they are secondary to a much more fundamental thing. The producer is the one who gets it done to the highest standard. 

This is what people get wrong about Rick Rubin. While he talks a lot about listening and "ways of being," that's not what makes a great producer. That's his personal application. What people miss is when he says "we work on the project until everyone involved thinks it's as good as it can possibly be. If we don't all think that *it's not finished*."

Phil Spector's version was "it's finished when *I* think it's as good as it can possibly be." But it's the same fundamental thing: across the finish line with highest possible quality.

Taste but with a relentless will to execute at the highest level.

author: Slow Hand
content: I once had to do three revisions with a ME to keep their masters from distorting in unwanted places. *Then* we found out that their hardware routing was also flipping the L/R imaging because their cabling was patched wrong. That was an artist-recommended ME. Needless to say, we did not go with them again.

author: popaganda.
content: An artist should never look for a “better” fanbase while leaving behind their diehards. Go ahead and piss your fans off with some challenging stylistic twist etc, but don’t suddenly start making music for a completely different audience at the expense of your current audience.

author: cian riordan
content:
Aside from the usual discussion about headphone preferences and HRTF, I’ll give you my experience with them.

I bought them a few years ago with the intention of just having a baller set of headphones for a bunch of travel I had coming up. I had tried them once at @oaklandmatt’s place and wasn’t super impressed... just thought they sounded like hyped headphones. But I really wanted something with killer noise cancellation and something to potentially reference Spatial mixes. After purchasing, the more I used them, the more I fell in love with listening to music on them. I realized quite early on that there was a lot of parity between how things sounded in the APMaxes vs. my PMC 6-2s… similar low end presentation, similar high end. But just genuinely enjoyed listening to music on them.

I was traveling for thanksgiving last year and a last minute mix opportunity came up for some video game trailer. Not my normal speed but they were up shits creek with a deadline and the money was good… so I mixed the whole thing start to finish on my laptop with the Airpods. I was a little sheepish about sending off un-vetted mixes, but the clients loved it and I saved the day. I curiously took a listen when I got back to my studio after the holiday and was very surprised that the mix was 98% there. There was maybe a small low end tweak I could’ve made, but by and large, the mixes translated incredibly well. 

Now I use them much more for odd tasks, usually revisions and printing sessions. I can be on my couch on my laptop running files down with transparency mode on, still hanging with my family while watching a show, and lock in with noise cancelling when I need to focus.

For $600 they’ve been a massive value-add to my work flow.

author: Will Melones
content: I can just imagine this scenario. A producer sequences all the drum parts, they do the demos, write the song and whatever. Then they book a session and Matt Chamberlain shows up with a pristine Drum-Doctor tuned kit and an invoice for cartage. “Ok, we want you to play exactly what’s on the track, we like that.” He’s a pro, so of course he does. They quantize the performance, finish the song, and send the track off to @cian riordan  who DRTs the drums and replaces them all with Steven Slate one-shots and buries the cymbals.

author: BatMeckley
content:
Id take this a step further… bring out the beauty in the subject. Songs that artists do with Noah tend to be better than the songs they did with someone else because not only is he working with talented people, but they’re more talented because they’re working with him. Matt Rad is good at this too. Cian just makes them feel taller.

author: Slow Hand
content:
I'll still follow the artist through an idea if they have a specific vision that I'm not hearing. Oftentimes that path can yield unexpected fruit.

It's not uncommon to spend two hours going down the "over-produced" route but the last idea that gets put onto the track may pair wonderfully with the simple "under-produced" version. We'll often end up rolling the song back to the "under-produced" version, but have a hook from the "over-produced" version that we wouldn't have gotten if we didn't take the long way to arrive back where we started.

author: BatMeckley
content:
It’s neat that there’s so many different approaches to producing a record, some people like Albini are almost strictly engineers capturing the artist warts and all, other people like mutt and fields are replaying everything and singing 90% of the BVs. (Once you hear Max Martin sing you can’t unhear him on all those boy band (and even Brittney) tracks. 

It’s such a weird balance of the ego, because as a producer you have to be arrogant enough to go “your art should sound like THIS” but you have to be humble enough to know when your idea isnt the best one. An up and coming pop band im far more likely to hard tune and really lock in their performances, where as if im cutting a Nels Cline or a Mimi Parker im more apt to go “well shit, that’s not what I would do, but who am I to try and dictate to you how to sound… here’s my gentle suggestion and if you say no, cool”

My general rule is put in the work, then take a step back, take a deep breathe, and try to accurately assess which is better… that decision you make is REALLY what defines you as a producer. So so so much of what I do ends up on the cutting room floor, but I wouldn’t have gotten to the end result without it.

author: BatMeckley
content:
<deep breath>
So, grasshopper, everything matters, and nothing matters. It depends on where you are and where you’re going, and most importantly actually knowing where you’re going.

I view the difference in shitty gear vs good gear as compound interest. A vintech one on one might sound basically like a vintage neve. ALMOST indistinguishable. But if you’re using it on all 149 of the tracks you’re compiling into a pop song, the end result is going to be 149 times more noticeable. The second floor of the leaning tower of Pisa looks pretty spot on but the people on the 15th floor are freaking out. 

That said, I could record a garbage singer through my 251 and my chain, and if I didn’t know what to do with it, it would still be garbage. The flip side is we actually demoed different mics and different chains on Paris Hilton. There was a right answer. And she’s not gonna win any singing contests, but at the end of the day the cumulative effect of all the decisions we made led to tracks that are still being played in clubs to make people dance over a decade later.

Details matter in not just what the audience hears eventually, but what the artist hears initially, giving them the confidence and headspace to sprinkle in their extra few (sometime more than a few) percentage points of vibe that the audience attaches too later. Fix it in the mix is an abused concept because it doesn’t take in to account the affect of shitty sound or feel on the performance. You think 1 mic doesn’t matter? I’ve heard people sing noticeably more in tune and in time when switching from DAW monitoring to direct monitoring. It ALL matters.

But if you don’t understand songs, melody, rhythm, and how these things interact to move people? None of it matters.

author: peterlabberton
content: And on the flip side: I once stayed up until 2 am while working on a record I was producing and put together a killer guitar part that I was somehow able to nail (with some significant editing). I listen in the morning and think to myself, "bite me, Blake Mills, I've got your fuckin' number asshole!" Artist comes in, I play the song back... "it's cool but it's not the vibe." And that was that—I think we put a Solina pad in there instead that took 3 minutes to do and we moved on.

author: BatMeckley
content: Of the successful people I know, some are incredibly granular, others can barely turn a knob in the studio, but they ALL get hyped when the song is right. They know when the turkey is ready so to speak. If you can figure that out, the rest takes care of itself pretty easy.

author: ALXCPH
content:
I've been a "musician" since way before i started recording and producing stuff. (Since i was 4 i think). It's such an integral part of how music can feel and make you move. Think about how someone like Anderson paak. can make you dance by just playing 8th notes on a highhat and nothing else(see tinydesk for ref.) or Pino Paladino, will make you break your neck with his bass, playing simple Quater notes. (anything D'angelo).  Even in a genre that is as quantized and on the grid as it gets like a lot of hiphop/trap is, notice how the artist(rappers) that really stand out, are the ones that make those beats really groove/hit because of how they themselves "groove" or flow on those beats. They might be slightly behind or in front of the beat, or they might even swing a little. 

You can really get into the micro and macro dynamics of groove. Listen to guys like Led zeppelin, how they might start out a song a few BPM slower than they finish, because of the build up of energy through out the song, and it doesn't sound wrong or unnatural. 

A fun thing to do, when looking for inspiration for grooves, is record some foley, and look for naturally occurring rhythms in the sample. Try and build a grove around that probably a bit wonky rhythm. It can really be an eye opening experience once you realise how much fun rhythm and groove is, when you don't have to obey the grid in a daw like a machine. 

But like anything music, it's really about listening and feeling. Really internalising what a forward or laid back snare feels like or a bass thats almost a 16th behind the beat.

author: Slow Hand
content:
Ok. One last example (since I've already gone this far). Miles Davis. 

Miles had the technical chops. He had fathomless musical depth. He could write every single note of a big band chart if he wanted to, but he (with a few early exceptions) never did this.

His recipe for music making was this: 

A) Start with a great song (chords and melody)
B) Curate a team of players with their own strong musical identities 
C) Bring them together and let them interpret the song
D) Direct them on feel and how to listen to and respond to each other

That's it. Miles' music was never about big arranging moments, or written-out parts. He started with great raw material, great players, and great prompting and then he let them roam free and play.

So that's one more way to approach it. 

There are two things that I keep coming back to in all of this: A great song and a vision. If you have those you can set your players free to surprise and astound you.

author: BatMeckley
content: I actually ended up working on the Fields record because I was touring (my friends had road cases that I needed, and they wanted my amps for their guitar sound on the record). I’ve found that just making music anyway I can has always managed to lead to work (ie, I produced a 3oh!3 song because the girl I was playing with on warped tour was on the same stage with them, we became friends, I started playing with them too, and then we just kept in touch.) But that song wasn’t until 2 years later. Doors of opportunity rarely open immediately, you just try to keep yourself in a shape that means you can walk through them when they do.

author: Zack Hames
content:
You’re gonna hate this. But the best way is to just get more reps to get faster and better. 10,000 hours, no shortcuts.

But more actionable advice - stick to a slim number of EQ and Compressor plugs and just use those. For example 99% of my mixes just use pro q3, API-2500, and Kush AR-1. The idea being minimize variables and decisions, and use stuff you know ridiculously well.

Production side, I find having go to sounds, samples, and instruments (hardware or software) well learned and ready to go shortens the path from opening your project to creating music. For me, this is taking my free time to mess with my MPC and explore samples, or to create patches on my synths to become more intertwined with my instruments. This is separate from the actual “I’m gonna make a song today” process.

Ultimately…make a song in 8 hours as many days as you can. If you TRY every day, that’s better than nothing. By the end of a month, even if you only made FOUR tracks…that’s better than nothing and it just adds up.

author: LAPhill
content:
By far, the most important element in realistic orchestral sound is in the programming. You need a controller where you can automate cc1 and cc11 (modulation and expression). Instruments, especially strings, are constantly changing their volumes. Particularly on entrances and phrase-ends. If you don't have a controller for this, you can draw it all in, but that gets really tedious.

If you get that figured out, I can almost guarantee that just about any library out there will get you good results. So then it's just a matter of what sound do you gravitate towards, how elaborate of a feature set do you need, etc. Legatos are overrated and I'd take no legato over a poorly programmed one any day.

If you want a full orchestra, not just strings, I'd check out some of the all-in-one offerings from Spitfire (Albion, BBC Orchestra, or Abbey Road), East West, Orchestral Tools (Inspire), or VSL (Prime). They all will have several different articulations, a decent amount of dynamic layers, and a full set of orchestral instruments. Have a listen to them and see what sounds grab you. Spitfire and Orchestral Tools have a more prominent room sound baked in, but they all do to some extent. So be aware that, whichever library you choose, there's a certain amount of "reverb" (which is actually just the hall they're recorded in) that you will never be able to turn off.

author: Slow Hand
content:
> "How are y'all thinking about which part of this waveform should fall on which side of the beat?"
I'm listening and not looking. Nudge. Listen. Nudge. Listen.

When it comes to groove or feel it's common for the ensemble to not line up perfectly or even *sound* as if they line up perfectly on transients. Quite often the band are flamming against each other in a way that is tasteful. Sometimes they're dead-on for a beat and the next moment they're doing a tight flam. 

Don't get lost solo'ing instruments. Keep the entire song section in perspective when you tweak. If you're having trouble making choices mute a few instruments, but don't solo.

Also, fader level has a massive influence on groove. Before you start editing too hard play with your fader balances and find the groove that way. Listen to how the proportion of instruments changes the groove. It may turn out you don't need to do much, if any, micro editing.

author: NoahNeedleman
content: Biggest thing here to recognize is the artist is the artist. I tell people this all the time, if you wanna be a good photographer, take pictures of beautiful subjects. You wanna be a great producer, work with great artists.

author: Ross Fortune
content:
Confirmed by Phil Collen that 98% of the Hysteria guitars were Rockman (and Adrenalise, the following album - although that was with the later Rockman where you could switch the chorus/verb/delay in and out).

The *jang jang jang* I was looking for was Phil's 1978 Fender Stratocaster (nicknamed "Felix"), picking one string at a time through the clean setting on the Rockman, avoiding the arpeggio effect of actually strumming a guitar.

author: SoundsLikeJoe
content: Sometimes for deadline work,  I use a "trust the numbers" or "trust the process mentality" and avoid the time sink of artistic minutia viewpoints.   Meaning...   don't be too precious about it. You know what levels "need" to be.  You know the approximate balance of things. Get it into the range of "that works well enough" and ship it....  Because you HAVE too.  Clients that are pushing against the deadline are (often) just making products, and that doesn't get the same creative refinement as real art. Truth...   some clients often can't even tell the difference in that last 10% of quality improvement anyway (advertising, corporate, broadcast).  Not that you shouldn't always strive to do your best...  but at some point your craft-skill at 80% of max is all they have budgeted for and all you have time to invest and is AMAZING in their eyes.  That's just how WORK is sometimes. Ship it.

author: Slow Hand
content:
I couldn't speak to the current state of samplers, but I've always wished that someone would build a bold sampler that wasn't afraid to be really wacky and full of unique characteristics. For starters:

1. Include a radio tuner. 
2. Maybe some really nice - but heavily colored - preamps.
3. Include all kinds of weird peripheral sensors like devices that pick up EMF signals or a few contact mics. Include a suite of effect plugins that are specially geared towards these input methods.
4. Super-intuitive resampling, time-stretching, and pitch-shifting features.
5. An algorithm that analyzes the dominant pitch of a loop and auto-maps it to a keyboard. It should be capable of re-orienting itself as the dominant pitch of a loop is adjusted.
6. Tracker-style sequencing capabilities.
7. An OTT-style compressor. Maybe something really trashy and blown-out like Devil-Loc or Vulf Compressor. Something that really messes with the proportions of a sample.
8. Easy and flexible integration of feedback loops.
9. Intuitive integration of polyrhythmic looping or sequencing.
10. A feature for easy implementation of Steve Reich 'It's Gonna Rain' style tape loop phasing.
11. Auto-bpm detection keyed off of designated inputs (ala Ableton).
12. Automated master tempo effects.

I could go on.

author: Slow Hand
content: One of the big reasons I got into making music is because I wasn't hearing the stuff that I wanted to hear. I kept listening to records and thinking "Yeah, but wouldn't it be *awesome* if they did (blank)?". That motivates me a lot. I am supremely bored by the thought of making records that sound like existing stuff. If I've heard it already, why bother? Someone has already done the thing and they're probably going to do it better than I ever could because they really care about it. It's my intuition that you have to create the thing that you most want to see expressed and bring it into the world through your own perspective.

author: BatMeckley
content:
There’s one specific actress/singer I’ve worked with a few times, and the second time she brought her mom over while we were tracking. Every time I complimented her after a take, she screwed up the next one. If I said a take was bad the next one would be great. The session quickly devolved in to me just saying increasingly awful things after every take, much to her mom’s delight who was laughing on the back couch.

I’ve said this over and over again on this server, but people skills and just sheer musical awareness and taste trump technical ability and gear every time (the how vs the why). If I’m needing Kirk to record an incendiary angry solo in the middle of a heavy, emotional song, I’m probably not gonna set up flowers in the studios and kick it off with a warm stone massage.  Your job as a producer is to get the best out of the artist, and a good producer will have a feel for what that specific artist needs.(A Rick Rubin specialty).

author: LAPhill
content:
We're not privvy to the conversations and the process that led to the results of finished songs. In the same way that sometimes the rough mix wins, sometimes that loop that you grabbed just to kick off ideas ends up unbeatable. Rerecord with different sounds, trying to match or improve the feel, but there was something about the way those Splice loops interacted that couldn't be beaten. Or just isn't worth the effort because now everyone is focused on making sure the vocal is perfect and the track is working. 

I'd take the best version of the song over some self-imposed creative high ground any day.

author: Slow Hand
content:
At the risk of stating the obvious, transitions can also be telegraphed through the instrumental writing too. Whether it's a drum fill, or a chord voicing that walks up/down into the next section, or tension in the melodic voices, or shortening the notes lengths (staccato, staccatissimo).

There's also idiomatic noises from the instruments. Guitars have string scrapes, headstock rakes, that cool chattering thing from tapping near the bridge with the edge of your pick. Pianos have big glisses, horns can squeal, bowed strings can sweep a fast legato scale up into the downbeat or do a large gliss.

Then there's foley. I get a *lot* of mileage from sound libraries made for film audio. Foley artists are some creative people and you can go far layering their sounds into instruments at the transitions.

author: oaklandmatt
content:
My experience is that the melody often dictates the vibe. Based on your description, it sounds like you may creating too much production first, before trying to make a hook. 

Certainly you can make a full track and then write on top of it, but in my experience a great song or hook comes earlier in the process, either before or along with a production vibe. 

I would say this is true for 90% of the music I make, and is the case with both of the successful future bass songs I've been a part of.

author: oaklandmatt
NoahNeedleman
content:
Idk man. I’m in the “ideas need to be auditioned not discussed” camp. Explaining why shit isn’t working to someone who believes it is- that’s a bad time. 

IME when you have a “let’s try it” attitude, gung ho for the exploration, trust gets built much faster. Artists start asking questions like “what do you think?” much earlier in the process when your approach is less “you’re wasting time” and more “fuck around and find out.” 

However, saying “ok, but to audition this idea properly it’s gonna take x minutes/hours… is that idea worth that amount of time to you?” If they say yes, then it’s gotta be a yes. 

The other thing is saying “let’s finish this idea first and then we can try that.” 

Sometimes you’re a doula, sometimes you’re a doctor.

author: Slow Hand
content:
I used to feel deflated when I discovered that records I loved were sampled or interpolated from pre-existing records; not written solely by the artist that I admired. Still do sometimes.

Another thing happened, though. It shortened the distance in my mind between my work and the achievements of these artists. Doing what they did no longer felt quite so far out of reach. It's not to say that I went out and started sampling records, but it gave me a deeper appreciation for the creative act and assured me that so much brilliance is rarely created in isolation. It's all building on the foundations of what others have done before.

It opened my eyes to having a dialogue between myself and the rich history of music. Music is plastic, malleable, and fluid. There's a hundred and more ways to make something wonderful and they're all equally valid if we don't let our sense of pride prevent us from savoring them.

author: Nomograph Mastering

author: oaklandmatt
content:
Copying your favorite songs is actually a great way to learn! I've done it a lot and continue to do it periodically, even after making records for like 25 years. 

Think of this like practice, not as how to make *your* music. Trying to make a note for note, sound for sound copy of a song you like forces you to make moves and choose sounds you otherwise wouldn't choose.

By practicing in this way, you accumulate skills that become part of your subconscious creative arsenal.

Again, at this early point in your journey, there really are no right and wrong ways to make things. The key is to just make as much stuff as you can, trying as many different methods as possible.

author: oaklandmatt
content:
@Zack Hames yeahhhh. watch the questlove video on youtube where he talks about d'angelo asking him to play crazy laid back and flammy too.

my general thought on timing is: behind the beat is more groovy and laid back (vocals, percussion, bass against the kick drum, etc) and ahead is intense and anxious (especially vocals).

there are many examples of groove being behind the beat as that's something people talk about a lot. definitely dive into that concept and play with laying different elements back off the grid.

but i LOVE talking about being ahead of the beat. purists complain that a lot of modern hip hop vocals are ahead of the beat and "off time." but when it's done well it makes the tracks SO exciting. lil durk, 21 savage, gucci, etc all have this excitement in some of the songs because the vocal are ahead. 

i've heard the argument that these guys are just amateurish in their skill. that might be true, but their natural groove and cadence works. also listen to kendrick on "Family Ties" where he goes in and out of being ahead of the beat and it sounds exciting as fuck when he does.

also "Icky Thump" by White Stripes is a song with vocals that are entirely ahead of the beat. clearly it's deliberate as jack white is a rhythmic genius (and the doubles are perfect). it adds this anxiety to the whole song that is SO dope.

author: Slow Hand
content:
How short are we talking here? 2 min? 1:30? 0:30? 5 seconds? There are examples of great songs at all of those lengths.

These days I don't think it matters that much. Unless you're aiming for radio play, in which case I'd argue that if your song is *really* short then people are less likely to be exposed to it.

From a cynical money-making standpoint, I think Spotify considers engagement with a song to have happened after the listener has listened for 30 seconds. I don't know what happens if a song is shorter than that.

If the song is good (but short) people will play it again. If the song is horrible then everyone will be relieved that it ended sooner. 😉

author: Zach Hughes
content:
Wanted to share some thoughts spurred on by a recent experience on here. So a local artist has hired me to produce two of her songs. Vibe is singer-songwriter, soul, RnB.

We tracked drums, bass, and keys live in the studio OD'd to scratch tracks we cooked up together. The scratch tracks / demos were just guitar vocal and we were really relying on the players to fill out the arrangements, but we knew more would be added down the line.

All the players were incredible. Could singe your eyebrows off with technical prowess and shredtastic chops. Tracks turned out great, still working on the arrangement, but..

This project has got me thinking more about the importance of how you present a song to session musicians and the 'space' you ask them to fill in a production. As well as the changing dynamics project to project affected by a revolving cast of participants, more fleshed out demos, etc... I find this a really interesting topic. Curious if anyone in the group has any unique experiences or insights whether as a producer or a musician.

I've found that the more I flesh out demos with the artist beforehand the more bound and limited the session players we bring in are based off our decisions. This can make ODs more efficient, add a clearer direction, but can also remove the opportunity for the player to really add something special. Sometimes I don't want to be too suggestive b/c I want the players to have more of a blank canvas to work with.

author: wilhelmjosephk
content: One thing I love to do to help me wrap my head around sounds and tools is basically “transcribing” a preset to a new initialized patch on the same synth. Keep hitting the keys as you go to see how copying each setting changes the sound, and see if the end result is the same when you think you’re done. Often you’ll be completely missing some modulator somewhere and you’ll really need to dig through the synth’s features to find something you didn’t know before. As a bonus, you can try the same thing but have the synth that the preset comes from and the synth you’re recreating it in be two different tools, like trying to remake you’re favorite serum patch in Pigments. Sometimes certain features will be missing outright and you’ll just have to use your ears to get close, but I find this really useful for figuring the inherent differences in the tools at my disposal. Best thing about both of these exercises is they only take about 10-15 minutes a patch, then you’re on to something new

author: BatMeckley
content:
I mean, at the risk of over simplifying what it is we do, just listen. If you’re getting too much consonant already, I certainly don’t recommend over hyping the consonant any further. 😂

It’s like “how do you know when to use the maag eq to boost the high?” Answer: when it doesn’t sound bright enough. 

The other night I was at a table full of very very very good producers and mixers, and a discussion on the merits of Serban broke out, and there was talk about compression and limiting and making something sound like it comes out of fm radio already and how that effects the human nervous system and… and i was just like, I dunno man, I always thought that we went to Serban because he made sure you could understand the words. Lol. I think a lot of times as producers we can very quickly lose the forrest from the trees and fixate on the upper harmonic character of spectre at a certain oversampling level and it’s like yeah, but man, your song doesn’t have a bridge and the melody is forgettable. It’s like the people that put $10,000 spinner rims on a $700 ‘88 Nissan Maxima. Worry about the color and consistency of the icing once you’ve baked a kickass cake, not before. 

(I also know you’re not the target market for this advice cause you’re already killing it, this is more for the people reading through the discord.)

author: BatMeckley

Ehhh but they weren’t always top mixers. They had to get there first. Yes, they get high level productions, but they also know how not to ruin them. It’s more about understanding what good actually is, and then getting there (or not going some other direction when they’re already on good)

This is a take on the “well so and so got a max Martin song, so OF COURSE they had a number one. Anyone would with a max martin song” without realizing there’s a reason Max gave that artist (and not someone else) that song in the first place. Everyone has to bring something to the table.

author: LAPhill
content:
Okay @Nomograph Mastering , so I think the analogy is a little off. Music is a conversation, but it's a conversation between performers. At it's best, the performance is authentic, transcendent, and speaks to our souls in a way that real-world conversation with words can't do. But it's heightened, exaggerated, hyper-focused. If the song is written ahead of time, it's more akin to actors interpreting a script. The words are written, the notes are there. Unless we're talking about jazz improvisation, which is the closest we come to real world conversation, but even then, it's translated and performed. As much as Miles was saying what he wanted to say, he was saying it that way so that an audience would hear it, it wasn't a private conversation.

Now, if you get incredible actors on a stage or in front of a camera, you can let them do their thing with minimal trickery, minimal edits, and it will move you to tears. The respond to each other and elevate the piece beyond what feels possible. Watch that same play as a community theater-level performance and feel nothing. The reality is that a lot of the artists that are coming through aren't Sidney Poitier. They're just not that good at making their music feel effortless. Not every play works as a film, and vice versa. Not every track benefits from having a band in a room. 

Confusing the genesis of songwriting (one person crafting both sides of a conversation) with the act of expressing that work (one person performing every part, a la Tom Hanks' motion capture of every character in The Polar Express). I know that ultimately you and I agree on the benefits of humans recording together, but the analogy feels too blurry to me.

author: Slow Hand
content:
Two recommendations. Both are books.

If you only get one I would pick up Michael Beinhorn's *Unlocking Creativity*. It is very heavy in laying out the pre-production considerations as well as working with artists. Michael cares a *lot* and it shines throughout. It illuminates a lot of practical considerations that fall through the cracks of other books.

Second, Phil Ramone's book *Making Records*. It's not exclusively about pre-production, but in recounting his career Phil offers a tremendous amount of practical philosophy on how to handle artists, shape a record, and solve problems. It's a very easy and gripping read about making records in the 60s through the late 90's.

author: Skyler Young
content: I was recording on an album and I heard a few tracks that a different bass player played on at the beginning of the session and the tone on his bass part was amazing so I asked the producer how he treated the bass to get that sound and he said he did nothing, it going through the same chain I was. And I was horrified cause my bass was sounding nowhere near as good and I knew the other player had the same type of bass. The only thing that could effect the sound was the tone knob and as soon as I moved it to around halfway it perfectly fit in the mix and sounded as good as the other bass player - has been the biggest key to getting a good sound in the studio

author: peterlabberton
content: Under 40 hz? If we’re taking *that* low, in my experience usually kicks benefit from sitting just slightly above that range, especially in rock—somewhere around 50-60hz. Usually they sound punchier and less flabby with just a touch of the super low lows rolled off. Basses can move around a bit more, obviously, but I also find that usually even if you have a fundamental around or below 40 hz, the first harmonic an octave above is usually what you’re actually interested in. Also it’s very song/arrangement/tempo (!) dependent! A slower tempo or less busy kick pattern or song arrangement will let you get away with loads more super sub stuff. Faster patterns will just sound like flabby mush with tons of sub.

author: Slow Hand
content:
Oh man. Good example.

Filmmaking - far more than record making - is a team sport. Kevin Parker can mostly make a record by himself if he wants to. But scant few people are going to make an entire film by themselves without a team, much less an excellent one.

I think most filmmakers get disabused of the notion of artistic purity very quickly and open themselves up to the necessity of compromise and collaboration if they want to accomplish anything.

Polymath filmmakers are very rare. And they usually live in the realm of low-budget film. Your John Carpenter's, and your Robert Rodriguez's, and (on the extreme end) your Shane Carruth's.

author: BatMeckley
content: I was just bringing it up to be a schmuck and mildly difficult (largely because DP’s camp was pretty difficult with us when we’re on intersecting tours forever ago)  but it does bring up an important TOTALLY UNRELATED TO YOUR SPECIFIC DANIEL POWTER situation point: we’re in the business of tiny differences making huge differences. You can get a Warm 47 for a grand or real 47 for 15 grand and they’re preeeetttyy  close. But the devil is in the details. The original Dare you to Move (I think that song has had 4 different versions now) is pretty close to the Fields version… Fields rocked up the drums a little more, and by far most importantly  had my sage input (and gear) for a more kickass guitar sound. The song went from a heavily pushed song that couldn’t quite get its footing for them to a massive multi platinum career defining hit. It can be frustrating to watch someone else turn something we got 95% of the way there into the thing that got released, but often times it’s that exact skill which makes them worth the investment from the label. Understanding that difference and learning how to bridge the gap is the whole secret to making a living in this business.

author: BatMeckley
content:
These are two different things.
If you are doing meticulous need to be unbothered nerd shit, it’s great to have someone to keep the artist entertained. 

I would lose my mind, and my intern, if they kept interrupting a creative flow to yap. 

Again, (again again again), this business is 20% understanding gear, and 80% understanding people. You have to know your artists. Often, id even argue more often than not, it’s the fuckery and the messing around that often inspires the best ideas. We tend to be very bad at being creative with a gun to our head. As a producer, I’m trying to foster that safety and relaxation, while taking a Birds Eye view of the conversation listening for anything that I can go “wait! THAT was a lyric” or a riff or whatever. That’s always worked much better than me staring at someone going “hush. Write.”

Occasionally, like the old Peter Gabriel SO story, you have to lock the artist in the room and tell them they can’t come out until they’re done. But most of the time that just gets the job done, rather than the job done well.

author: Rollmottle
content: Some of my most creative thinking and best ideas come during wildly unfocused time. The same principle as passive listening -- you hear something totally different and it might be revealing in a way you can't access while actively listening. I think it's dangerous to try and impose rules around how somebody is most creatively fertile. It's different for everybody and may manifest in ways that aren't how they manifest for you. It's important to recognize whether it's truly them or is it actually you. You could certainly propose trying different approaches together to see what that sparks (more like Oblique Strategies), but best to be clear on what's driving what you're feeling lest you inadvertently kill the vibe or shut down a path.

author: sinaigimenez
content:
I liked his book, and yeah, I definitely like some of his records. I'm not dissing Michael at all. But some parts of his talk sound kinda weird to me. He’s always saying that music nowadays is at its lowest point when it comes to artistic expression, that it doesn’t connect with people anymore because it’s lost its “true expression” and blah blah — the usual “everything was better back then” speech...

To me, that just sounds like a guy who had better days professionally, didn’t really keep up with the times, and now complains about how bad everything is.

It also feels like he’s more into talking about music and art than actually making it. There’s something about his whole vibe that makes me think there are way more words than music coming from him. 
Talking and thinking about art is important, no doubt, and I love reflections about music that makes me think.

Then I think of someone like Tchad Blake — who, by the way, is older than him — and he’s the complete opposite. A guy who could’ve retired already but is out here doing the most innovative, bold mixes of his career and working on super exciting music.

I get super suspicious whenever someone says music sucks now. Like, really? Then I think about Radiohead, Idles, Autolux, Kendrick, Failure, Skrillex, Wilco, Kenny Beats, Björk, Alabama Shakes, NIN, Kacey Musgraves, Deftones, St. Vincent, Telefon Tel Aviv... the list goes on ad infinitum. Are you kidding me? That’s total BS.

That said, I still follow him on social media and enjoy reading some of his thoughts. I learned a lot from his book — but honestly, I’m not sure I’d want someone with that mentality producing my music.

author: BatMeckley
content:
That list is full of bands who had their biggest moments 15-20 years ago 😂. 

Though I do agree there is some incredible music being made right now, I do often think about the LWMR round table when I asked everyone what their favorite mix of all time was and no one mentioned anything modern.

Due to the total democratization of music now (ANYONE can have a song on Spotify by the end of the week) and the AI mixing tools we have, someone with virtually no knowledge or talent can have a passable sonically balanced but ultimately garbage track released. Combined that with algorithmic playlisting and dubious Spotify practices, I don’t think the idea that “there’s a lot more garbage music these days” is simply “old man yells at cloud”.

I’m a big believer that Good is the enemy of Great.

author: Zach Hughes
content:
I've been melodyning vocals for a ten song album past couple weeks and feel like I've leveled up my chops significantly. I'm no Beckley, but browsing whats been previously shared here and trial and error has been the mechanism of growth for me.

I kinda had the note separation tool workflow down from work in other programs. I've been experimenting with the time tool and attack speed tool as well as formant shifting to mask when the tuning becomes more audible than I'd like. That's probably where I'd pinpoint the level up for me personally. That and trying to be more conscious about not relying too much on the graphical UI. Unless it's something that really calls for hard tuning I lean towards wanting it to feel invisible / natural. Im realizing more what parts of the note actually need to be more 'on' and which can be more 'off' or just left alone. That and letting notes naturally drift to become more sharp as they tail off. If I'm too heavy handed it starts to feel lifeless to me. I'm also appreciating more the nuance of how one might approach different genres or styles with melodyne. Its humbling how powerful the program really is.

There've been a few moments with the attack speed tool that have felt like magic curing some subtleties of the performances that bug me, but I don't feel super confident that I have a grasp on that one yet. I've been working in standalone and importing a REF mix. For some reason I feel more confident dealing with esses in protools with RX or clip gain than I do melodyne idk why. Some frustrations have been flipping back and forth between tracks when tuning multiple files feels real clunky. I might be missing something about how best to do that. I wish, like with RX monitor, you could hear the vocal through your mix chain when tuning (is that possible?). Being able to rename exported files would be nice too like in RX.

author: Slow Hand
content:
One tip I'd give is to make your patch while you have a MIDI sequence playing. Not just some static, even arpeggio that you drew in, but a part that has different articulations, note lengths, velocities, and covers a range of notes.

It's easy when making a patch to just keep your finger on one key and go *doot doot doot* (tweak) *doot doot doot* (tweak again). What you can end up doing this way is optimizing the patch and parameters for a single note or handful of notes. And it gets old to listen to. By keeping the entire musical part playing you're going to move through building a well-balanced patch much quicker.

If you have a part in mind, record the MIDI with your starter/init patch, spend some time tweaking the patch while the sequence plays, and then once you get into the ballpark replay the MIDI part using your new patch. The new synth settings will influence your articulation and feel when you record the second time around. Then refine your patch as needed. Rinse and repeat until you're satisfied.

4 years ago is when I started producing with my buddies in a niche of the rap world. we considered doing type beats to 'get our names out there'. author: Deleted User
content:
I had this one particular vocal session where I was fucking up and all my comments were messing with the artist’s flow. So about an hour or two into the session, I got real with the artist and said “I feel like I’m being too much of a control-freak and my comments seem to be distracting you. Why don’t we take a break? When we come back, let’s forget about everything I mentioned earlier and see how things come out when you express freely. I have a feeling that it’s gonna turn out way better. I’m sorry, I think I got it your way” 

then after the break, the artist started nailing the takes. Not in the exact way I imagined, but in the best possible way that we were capable of THAT DAY. 

Since then, I decided to let go of control a bit more and let the artists do their thing as much as I can. I started developing ears for hearing what artists can work on before the session to get a better recording to my best of ability (if I get to know them before the sesh). I would only mention the simple things that can be improved with small adjustments short-term. That way the session can be more experimental and wild as opposed to fault-finding.

author: BatMeckley
content:
It’s been my experience that the directors usually have no clue what they actually want. I had another brief where they wanted “super modern” “hits of today” where they’d ref’d a dua lipa song, gave them something that was so close it probably wouldn’t have cleared copyright, then they said “no, more like this” and gave me a song that was 8 years old (that i actually had the stems for) , used THE ACTUAL stems and they were like “we can’t use it those stomps sound like gunshots” when it was the EXACT TRACK that they’d ask me to reference. 

The corporate hustle is learning how to interpret what they say they want with what they actually mean is how they want it to feel, and then being prepared to have it go through a dozen not musician hands, with each person having to give notes to justify their job. It pays well but it is about the farthest thing from “being creative and making music” as it gets.

They are almost never on the bleeding edge of what’s cool, and that’s fine, you just need to go in knowing that.

author: BatMeckley
content:
I really like the range function. There’s something in the way that it reacts that I just can’t get ProMB to sound the same. (And I’ve tried). 

I tend to be doing pretty wide, easy, just a few DB moves with it. The sharp resonant notches I used to use have been MOSTLY replaced by eq or soothe. 

You don’t have to use all the bands. Less is more. 

The whole reason I c6 over c4 is the side chain feature, where I’ll just have it last on say the guitar bus, triggered by the vocal, just ducking enough space to make the vocal a bit more intelligible. Bit like the song mixing itself. 
I find I’m not using c6 a ton on the actual track, it’s always side chained. 

C4 is more on the track itself. Really handy to focus a chunk of the audio. You can control the range of say 2-5k, and then move the entire volume of that up and down as it only dances with 5db of itself. Useful.

Not sure if I’ve mixed a song where the c4 isn’t on the drum bus somewhere.

author: Slow Hand
content:
Three things come to mind: 

1) **Note length and envelope**. That's going to have a large influence on the feel. Electronic producers will spend a *lot* of time sculpting the volume envelope relative to the tempo. Trance producers have entire plugins that give them microscopic control over the pitch and volume envelopes of kick drums.

2) **Presentation and proportion**. Is it up-front or does it sink into the back? It's easy for a 4x4 to feel hackneyed or overbearing. Sometimes all you need is a gentle *pat pat pat pat* to tie things together.

A fresh or unconventional texture will open up drastically different feels. People can dance to anything if it's got a 4x4 click, so it doesn't necessarily *need* to be a kick. You can go far using samples and percussion that sit in different registers, but play the same role.

3) **Complimentary instruments**. If the kick is the "rock" then the groove is going to come from how everything else swings over that. What's the friction like between the kick and the other elements? If the kick is a "straight man", then the other elements pushing off of it are where the magic comes from.

Because the money she is saving by using a newer mixer is gonna be made up for in the extra time it could take to get to the right mix. 

Now if the kid is working for free some issues could arise with time management and whether he would prioritize the work, so it could be healthy for that to be a conversation with the artist’s friend early on. If you end up circumventing the downsides of the inexperienced/free friend, it could be a win win for everyone, but that’s a big-ish “if”. Curious about other’s thoughts on this approach @cian riordan

author: Ross Fortune
content:
Yeah. Personally I *love* being given direction by artists. As long as it’s not overly prescriptive (“now click here, then turn drive to 5”), I can interpret what they’re imagining and achieve it through the filter of what I can anticipate will work well. But the results of those sleigh rides are always way more interesting to me than whatever I would’ve come out with left to my own devices.

Have to say the OP1 is a great toy to shove in any artist’s hand though. I still don’t know how to use it either, so we’re both just chimping it like the start of 2001 Space Odyssey, and wild stuff usually comes out.

Toys are good, I think folks just need to implicitly understand they can pick up anything they like in your room and have at it. So it’s about creating an atmosphere where everyone knows their input is valued and that it could be the stepping stone to something great, even if it’s not the end result itself.

author: oaklandmatt
content:
I will say I don't think it's all about their vision or when they want to pivot. It's a bit more nuanced. 

If you are truly a producer collaborator (as opposed to a hired gun engineer or musician), it's about trying all the ideas and collectively deciding what's best. But remember YOU are the one who holds the keys to the execution of the artist's ideas. You can have ideas and try them yourself, but if the artist has ideas, it's still YOU that has to execute them (because presumably they're not a producer like you). 

So you're actually building a big creative trust by helping the artist try stuff. If you can execute ideas that the artist can't quite articulate or do themselves, you gain a credibility where you can both listen and then say "Ah, I see what you mean. I think this other version is best."

author: chrissorem
content: I was in a similar situation last week, and  there were a few times where I found myself thinking, “shit this has turned for the worse, how do I steer us back to main land”. What I concluded was you have to be patient and let them try the ideas hear them out and if you feel strongly about something, tell them what you feel in a way that makes them feel like you care and explain without it becoming a speech why you aren’t feeling the idea. And try to follow it up with an idea that you think works.  In my case I  said “ we all love the foundation and we landed somewhere and that feels good. Now we have to be disciplined and be sure that anything we add is truly adding and not taking us away from our northern star.”  And if you think they have bad ideas that they are glued to, ask questions, why do you feel this part has to be here, what is it doing for the song as a whole? Ect. For an arrangement you should be able to hash that out quickly, there are only so many options

author: Slow Hand
content:
I don't fault anyone for playing a game of interpersonal relations. Both approaches are valid and I see the necessity. I just as often see great art corrupted by non-artistic motivations, and I tolerate it because very often that's what is necessary for things to get done, albeit imperfectly from the perspective of artistic purists.

It's rare for an artistically pure viewpoint to endure. Very rare. Just as often it requires a more nuanced understanding of what it takes to make the show happen. It takes compromise. It's great when it can happen in an ideal way, but idealism doesn't make a thing so.

author: NoahNeedleman
content:
Another example:

On Brett’s last record, he did a demo with a co-writer of a song I loved. he tracked vocals with me, and I suggested the track needed a Mayer style guitar solo, so I played it. When Dann Huff heard it he told Brett “we’ll just upgrade Noah’s track to Master Scale. It’s not gonna get any better than that.”

When they went into the studio, they ended up taking the Mayer idea all the way, and the whole thing kinda went Country “Don’t Trust Myself.” They couldn’t do a Mayer solo on top of a Mayer vibe cause it would go from inspired by to straight derivative. 

My solo didn’t make the record, and I didn’t get any production credit. But the guy who did the demo did. I did get some BGVs on it and paid accordingly. All that felt right to me.

I had done a little brainstorm session with chatGPT actually to help me create a daily schedule oriented solely around writing which was pretty helpful. But even when still in the production grind I like having guitars laying around so I can grab one when I take a break or bring on in the house with me. If you have the flexibility, w/o compromising deadlines, I've found it helpful to leave room to indulge the moments when songs / melodies / lyrics pop into my head even when my expectation that day was to work on a mix or other production. Be interrupted by the song and push everything else back an hour and see what happens.

Less of a workflow and more of a philosophy thing…

When I record/produce I’ve always been in the practice of putting the artist first. For comping, i have traditionally seen recording takes on one day, then going through them with the artist as a way to make sure their performance is as intended. 

I’ve recently comped a few things on my own, and realized how much faster it is. 

Now I’m thinking if I have an attended comping session with an artist, maybe I should go in with my comp as a starting point, maybe this will get us to the finish line sooner. 

Thoughts on this?

author: Zach Hughes
content:
Ooo I love this question. I'm currently on a journey with this idea that 'arranging is mixing'. There are a few things I've learned / frameworks that have been helpful to me recently.

I have noticed that in the past in my own approach to production (as well as with some clients who send me their productions to mix) the way I thought about building the track was like assembling / stacking static blocks on top of each other. This realized more as a mental construct and not fully so in practical application. Intuition still served. But this framing became problematic and I think is endemic in music created with primarily loops and samples.

I remember hearing Jon's comments on his 'temporal approach' to mixing which he wrote about on his site (I believe a link surfaced here a few months back). Some of the language Jon used was helpful to me (i.e. painting with sound). I started to think about my productions instead like film. Each second of each section of the song is a new scene unfolding. Every type of processor then becomes a way to adjust and enhance the emotion of the characters in the story. Not static but changing and adapting to align with the central spirit of the song. I tried to find more useful metaphors (i.e. sommelier of sound, a song tour guide, like I was piloting a space ship and mix elements were asteroids). It's one thing to lay down some parts and call it a song and another to consider what is the experience of these parts through time. I think less experienced engineers and often artists who record themselves are not considering pretty much every one of @Slow Hand 's points which creates a real challenge for the mixer.

author: cy (sigh)
content:
@Ross Fortune  @spectrummasters 

pretty much hit the nail on the head on a lot of it. it does have a basic name and was originally mostly popular in West and Central Africa, where msot of the slaves that went to the Caribbean were from.  I'm just blanking out on the name rn. 

that rhythm, or a form of it present in almost all popular Caribbean styles of music. 

reggae, reggeaton, dancehall, zouk, konpa, salsa, soca etc all have their versions of it w some of them essentially not having any difs. 

i think things kind of went full circle for various cultures. rose of reggeaton in the 90s in the Caribbean (2000s in the US) which became the first Caribbean genre after reggae/dancehall  to really hit the international stage hard brought a lot of those back to the forefront.  

around the same time a boom in zouk / konpa music started happening in African countries (a lot of acts started touring there). 


afro house then afro pop and all subcategories started making rounds in Europe (at least the French speaking countries)  and the Caribbean in 2010s and hitting  us soil full strength a couple years after that (w some exceptions)

all this culminating in the now where you'd be hard pressed to not here a handful of these rhythms on the radio in most countries. even I was surprised that one of the biggest intl hits was a haitian song and they ended up having a remix w burna boy. 

but yeah I find it super interesting how the same core  rhythms is delivered under so many names.

author: Zakhiggins
content:
Im pretty much always messing with the length of kick, snare and hat trying to get them to fit in the grove better, you can make some unlikely pairs work when you do this.

Also always messing with the order in which transients are hitting on downbeats, nudging certain drums slightly before or after others can make things mesh together real nice. Typically the higher pitched/attacky things like hi hats come earlier than the sub kicks for example but experiment with it and see what sounds good. A song where this is really obvious is say it right by nelly furtado, listen to the way the layers are stacked on the downbeats of the chorus. Side note, when you're doing this, think of everything with a transient on that downbeat as a percussion instrument.

author: Slow Hand
content:
If they're loops I always include the tempo in parentheses at the end of the file name *ex: Plaque perc loop 1 (130)*.

If they're one-shot drums I always prepend them with  *kick, snare, HH, OHH, etc* An example would be *kick Plaque 1*, *kick Plaque 2*, etc.

If it's a collection of all the sounds and loops from a finished song I create a folder for that song (with the tempo in the name) and within that folder are subfolders for *loops, drums, SFX, etc*

Finally, in addition to creating a folder with all of the assets for the songs (as I just mentioned), I copy all of the drum-hits to a single folder that has all of my custom *kicks, snares, HH, etc*. Same for any loops. This way I can search by song, but I can also go to a folder with *all* of my custom kick samples in one place.

author: Deleted User
content:
I feel you, especially in boom bap there's a lot that goes into that drunken swing feel. Same with tradition African groove. Easiest way is to load up a clip or loop from a drummer you like and extracting groove templates. You can quantize to the groove of your favorite drummer or a drum loop you dig. This will get you the results, but groove is a never ending journey of learning. Editing groove to make it feel the way you want to feel takes an understanding of what makes things groove one way or the other. It can be accents, dynamics, lengths of the notes, how much you deviate from the grid or what subdivisions you're on, and how the timing offsets rub and interact with each other in the whole instrumentation. Some drummers have really solid quintuplet swing, so instead of doing tripplet swing they'll play on the downbeat and the 3rd or 4th note of quintuplet. For this you can listen to guys like Nate Smith, he plays swings differently live than recordings- he drags and pushes the kicks and snares in recordings but for live, he only swings hats so there's more steady groove for other musicians to grab onto. 

On the other hand, for playing the grooves yourself- I find it helpful to dance and groove to the rhythms as much as I can to absorb the feel and internalize them. But in order to play ahead or behind with authority, you need to know where the grids are and metronome practice is crucial. I'm not that great at timing either, so I'm trying to do as much reps in with metronomes as I can. Learning to play on the grid is a first step before learning how to deviate with clear intention. I hope this helps!

author: spectrummasters
content:
yes agreed, production wise you can follow those roland drum kits pretty much through every decade to this day. its amazing to me that a number of todays budding producers can name these things partially, for example referring to the Roland 808 Kick Long and not know anything about the Roland 808, let alone the other modules. ......and parrallel to the "808 ", the 909 is still to this day, going strong in house with the likes of MK . From a production/mix viewpoint....i suppose these sounds themselves hit with such a charcter in the right frequencies that there must be something intrinsically appealing to us that will keep them forever relevant.Im diving back into the Linndrum Clap and the old Jermain Dupri / So So Def claps at the mo for a little diff sonic character .....they are all still in the same ilk as the rolands though. 

re: the drill hats.....thats another cyclical pattern there. In the uk thats been appearing and reforming for decades now. its a soca pattern that the uk appropriated into a period of uk garage production (about the same time that 2 step began to mutate into the hip-hop influenced So Solid style )......and then dipped into a scene we had follwing called UkFunky ( a mix of Us House and Carribean influenced drum patterns and bass) . Then it re-appeared again in those drill hats once the uk appropriated/re-mouldedd chicsago drill

author: Slow Hand
content:
I don't know that music being hard is necessarily a good thing for it's own sake. I'd rather have it be easy and lower the friction between conception and realization. A lot of tech these days enables that ease and has opened the door to more people writing and producing their records.

But a secondary side-effect that I think we can all observe - and I think this is more to your point - is that musicians are leaning into those methods and not pursuing the hard work and practice that is necessary to do things like singing well, or playing piano with more than a base level of proficiency, or orchestrating an ensemble well. The expressive unlock of being highly proficient isn't being pursued like it was in the past decades (before we had so may technological means). People are - broadly speaking - more satisfied these days to settle for records that don't push into that potential.

What we lose are the heights of expression that virtuosity unlocks. Whether that's singing like Aretha Franklin, or playing a simple ballad like Bill Evans, or writing a song with as much sophistication and lyrical wit as Joni Mitchell.

author: LAPhill
content:
Oooh I have a theory here, about cultural values. Audiences in the 1800s, for instance, could go to a symphonic concert and recognize sonata form, key centers, etc. There was an appreciation for the form of the music and the virtuosity of the player first and foremost. Acknowledgement of skill. Making things seem effortless was the ideal.

Contemporary listeners seem to connect more with the struggle. They want to hear the grit in the vocal, the player at the edge of their ability (whatever it may be) holding on for dear life. The mix at the edge of distortion. In that breaking point, there is a lot of beauty and emotion that would have traditionally been considered bad form. Uncouth, even!

At the end of the day, if you don’t make a song that does well enough you’re probably not going to have to worry about people booking you much anyway. I don’t know a single person in town who’s like, “I’m paying this guy for session after session even though he never delivers results but man is he a fun hang”. 

I would posit that your job as a producer would include (if you HAVE to invite over the temperamental yet always delivers results songwriter) making sure you’ve set up the session that her shitty attitude doesn’t ruin it for everyone else. Again, the job of the producer really comes down to maximizing the strengths and minimizing the weaknesses. That doesn’t just apply to a kick sound.

author: Deleted User
content:
I’d like to challenge the idea of “the performance you need”. Do you need it? Who needs it more? 

As a producer, you’re gonna have another project soon. And you can even remove it from your discography playlist if you really don’t want people listening to it. BUT Artists have to live with the record. 

What I believe is that there’s performance that both the artist and I need. And that is an honest performance. If there are things that can be addressed easily and quickly, by all means go for it. But it’s still important to be careful to not let that inject any doubts in the performers. I fuck up on this all the time, even though I fuck up less the more I do it- it’s still not an easy thing to do. It’s not even a person to person thing.. it’s a moment to moment thing. I find it necessary to gauge how they are feeling and what else is going on in their minds and lives that may be getting in the way of being at their best. A 15 minute conversation may serve the session better than doing 15 minutes of more takes.

author: SoundsLikeJoe
content:
That last sentence of the first paragraph has weight imo. It also brings up a HUGE philosophy consideration that most musicians are uncomfortable wrestling with....


Craft vs Art.  You can be a music craftsman that has huge success and have never made personal artistic output. Art doesn't equal market value and market value doesn't rank art. 

Making with Splice can be rewarding and make a craft product of market value....  and it might even be transformative and unique enough to be art...  but it could just as easily be basic craft work without any intrinsic artistic value or personal expression.  It's a wide gradient of subjective value judgements.

author: Slow Hand
content:
Pick a something from a song that you like and teach it to yourself. Maybe a melody, some chords, or a cool voice leading thing.

As you try it, play around with transposing, changing the tempo, stretching it out, or compressing the time. I find that playing with something like this gets me in the mindset and before long I’m inspired enough to use the idea as a jumping-off point.

author: KushKadett
content: Dub and raggae from that era was made on old BBC consoles (very hifi and not lofi gritty in my book) There's an engineer giving a masterclass on dub mixing on youtube (great video, highly recommend it!)  and he explains how it's kind of a misconception that their equipment was all ghetto when in actuality they had incredible world class stuff left over from the brits after they left, which rivals what the best studios use even today. Analog gear hasn't really progressed much and a pultec/Neve EQ is still one of the best EQs ever for instance. Those records still sound great for that reason. As for punk and hardcore it's interesting: do people genuinely still listen to those records? I've revisited a few old punk records which I used to think were amazing. The songs are great but the listening experience just isn't enjoyable for me anymore, in part due to messy playing  and bad recording/mixing. With bad I mean the playing distracts from the groove of the band and the mixing distracts from the song, where it does not support the dynamic shifts

author: peterlabberton

I think the example of great punk/post punk/early indie records is perfect: great music but poor sonic quality and sloppy playing—at least by many peoples’ standards. The Replacements Let It Be is fucking rad, but would I use that as a mix reference for how I want something to *sound*? No!

On the other side of the coin, I feel like a *ton* of current/recent music can sound really good from a technical production/sonic perspective, but be totally void of any emotion that I connect to. So would I ever put it on to listen to for pleasure? No!
