author: ALXCPH
content:
(It’s all super project dependant) If I’m both producing and tracking I’ll often just get the production to a point where it’s good to write to and simple enough to have ideas flow. Then throw it into a vocal tracking session and get the demo vocals and get the song written and record a few too many parts. Then produce the song around the song and vocals. Usually I’ll have beat and vocals separate, but sometimes it makes more sense to have in the same session. Depends on the song. But I always track over a 2 track. Because it takes a lot of risk out of having some random synth or plug-in chain from the production mess up the session while trying to get good takes with the artist.(total buzzkill if you have to restart a session when the vocalist is in the zone) 
But again soooooo project dependant. Depends on how the artist likes to work, time line, amount of sessions that are possible to have together and so on. Sometimes you’ll only have one day with an artist, and if you are also producing, leave all the cool production tricks til later and get the best vocals you can get.

author: Daniel Ross
content: I feel like groove is so subjective so we’re probably all wrong and all right to some degree…but I almost never let my bass be off grid. I always find the impact lessened when I do. Something about a lack of confidence in the low end makes me like the song less. There are exceptions but they are rare imo. And I hardly ever let the down beats of transitions be off grid too. I usually want the sections to be obvious. I also start with going behind the beat first. I have also recently in the last year or so found that if I start with getting the very basic part of the groove right first, I am less likely to overcrowd my production. So before I put hats in, I’ll just put in snare and kick and try and find the groove with just those 2 elements (unless there is some other clear rhythmic element at play) but I feel like if you can’t feel the groove with just the kick and (snare/clap/perc) then it’s not there.

author: Slow Hand
content:
I agree with @BatMeckley's approach on this. Have them execute your vision, and then once you have it let them go wild and swing big. Try something new.

It's up to either the artist or you, as the producer, to have a vision for what the song is, where it's going, and what it needs. One of you have to have a roadmap. *Someone* needs to have the vision. To be the leader. To steer the ship.

If the vision is not clear then perhaps the song itself needs to be refined some more until it has a strong identity. That will be your north star for creative decisions. 

If you can convey the essence of the song to your players, the emotion behind it, then they can interpret that feeling in a way that is uniquely them without the need for you to dictate their parts. If you can give them an emotion and maybe some general contour of what you're hearing then they can fill in the spaces and bring their own qualities.

As producer, part of your job is curating the talent that you recruit to realize your vision. If you know what the song needs you can confidently pick a player with complimentary sensibilities. If you can pick the right person then very often most of the work is done by virtue of them being aligned with the song. Each of their contributions and ideas are likely to be excellent.

----

author: Slow Hand
content:
If you're concerned about being too suggestive to the players about their parts then strip back the demo until it contains only the most essential parts. No fancy stuff. Just chords, melody, and lyric. *Maybe* a kick drum pattern. Lead sheet style.

If the song is good then it will still be compelling. The best songs tend to be very robust and can be played a dozen different ways because they are fundamentally compelling. If the demo doesn't feel good this way then the song may need more work.

Lesser songs will depend on the arrangement or production to be compelling, or only work in a narrow band of styles. Sometimes a song can only work one way. It's okay if this is the case for your song, but then it's up to you to present the demo with the arrangement or elements that are essential to make the song compelling, and that will close off more and more of the instrumental possibilities.

So if you want to increase the chances of a session player delivering an unexpected, brilliant, idea then set them up for success with a strong song that can be interpreted many ways.

----

author: Slow Hand
content:
Totally. And there's a way to convey all of this without being hamfisted about it. 

Believe you me, I *hate* the feeling that I'm being pitched to. If I get a whiff of it without having asked for it I have an allergic reaction.

A lot of people don't know what they don't know. They don't understand how much effort goes into tuning or finessing a vocal performance. From their perspective they laid down a great one and when the final comp shows up sounding amazing they might assume that all you did was comp a few takes, EQ, add some compression and *voila*. They don't know about the hours and hours you spent getting it all just-so, listening, and then adjusting again. Not to mention your years of hard-won judgement that allow you to know when it's the correct move. That's all invisible to the client.

Of course, pros will likely know all of this because they've had the experience enough times. They're less likely to challenge you on why your all-in fee is at such a level.

author: LAPhill
content:
Any thoughts on how to convey value, given these dynamics then? I doubt many people here would think that going into detail about the behind-the-scenes process is the answer. To the client/artist, the work either resonates or it doesn't, elevates or not. And that's how it should be. Helping people zoom out and focus on the FEEL difference that's been made seems like a start, but as we all know, it can be hard to see the forest for the trees. And if the artist is hyper-focused on how much reverb is on the vocal, they're losing the context of WHY the decision was made, and how it feels as a whole. 

I don't have answers here, but I'm curious of other's thoughts.

author: ALXCPH
content:
What this guy Said! 👆a great Groove by great players on the way in usually needs very little work. 
If you do have to edit, going completely on grid i almost never the way to get “Groove”.
If you listen to how they interact try and feel why its not grooving. Are some beats rushed or maybe too sluggish? The best grooves are usually a little bit of very consistant not on beatness. 

Other than that you could have something that does Groove on the Way in, but if the rest of the material isnt grooving with it, things will still Sound off. 

Groove is instinctual and intentional. And like with anything its hard to why something is not grooving if your ears havent spent the reps listening and analysing what a good Groove sounds like. 

I know i might be over explaining. But incase someone else is reading and can get something from it. 🤓

author: spectrummasters
content: Aha ! I did not realise this . At all . I appreciate and use the action of clippers carefully but had not realised that they do this . My level of understanding was that instead of squashing peaks down (a la comp / limiter ) they just shaved them off and so the rest of the material could remain less compressed for the same rms . I’d not realised at all that those clipped peaks are  sort of returned / recycled into the signal . Fascinating . Thanks for the enlightenment man . I’ll have to read up on that . And this fact of course gives evidence to your point that using a delta is a longer way round to try and achieve much the same . I listened to the delta in kotelnikov and couldn’t see how it could sound musical to return that to the mixbus . It sounded like the sound of mp3 stream buffering glitches , so I figured I must not have understood something and left it at that . With the potential imo for phase issues I left the idea behind , but I was intrigued if Ryan’s comment about deltas pertained to the same thing . Another lesson learned here today . Thank you for the explanation

author: Deleted User

Most synths come with manual page with SysEx (system exclusive). If you want to use hands, it will automatically pick up the parameter automation and record into the daw as long as you have hooked up midi in and midi out. Some synths can just do this with usb. 
If you are drawing in the automation, then you can reference the SysEx page to find out which midi cc corresponds to the parameters.

author: Deleted User

I don’t think you want to crush artists’ or performers’ confidence. You want them to stay confident. The moment doubt enters the room, the magic can start falling apart. What you need is an encouraging honesty that allows them to believe themselves even more than they would if they were to do it all on their own. In my world, that’s what I am hired to do.

confidence can show up differently in different circumstances. In certain occasions, “this guy knows what I need to do make this recording come out better” is what brings them confidence. Which can sometimes mean pushing them harder. Or it can mean that I don’t say anything at all. Or telling them not to sweat about certain details because there are more important things to focus on

Compassion is a necessity and one of the most important qualities of a producer in my humble opinion. I gotta be able to tell what they need to be at their best at that very particular moment

author: Adam Thein

This is probably repeat info but I like to split the audio between transients manually then use the Shift+Option+Command (on mac) combo and click drag the audio to slip the audio within the clip, then slice the next transient and you can get into a flow pretty fast and manually slice up an entire take pretty quickly.  Multimic sources like drums I do the same thing but with the "Link Tracks" option.  Can usually fly through a full song pretty quickly.

Especially for acoustic guitars, drums, and vocals that are super sensitive to warping this is usually my method in Ableton.

author: Slow Hand
content:
Yes. This is huge. As you lengthen the pre-delay it simultaneously makes the back wall of your mix sound farther away *and* makes your source (let's say a lead vocal) sound closer to the listener. It's the separation and contrast between the two elements that gives this definition.

On the other hand, using a short pre-delay time and "gluing" the verb to the source can make the source sink backwards into the mix as you balance your fader level and the dry/wet level.

Definitely keep the lead separate. 

Think about how this artist might want to split things up. In most cases the doubles will want to be separate from the harmonies, but it depends on the arrangement. Sometimes big chorus harmonies don’t sound full without the doubles, for instance. But if you keep them separate they can choose what to keep and what to mute.

author: LAPhill
content:
Years ago, I had to create a soundalike of a Miley Cyrus song, starting with the tempo. I discovered that it had a carefully constructed rise of 1bpm every 4 or 8 bars, for the first intro/verse/prechorus, until landing something like 6bpm by the first chorus. It was one of those "aha!" moments for me.

Just because you're recording to a click doesn't mean you can't build in some of a musician's natural tendencies to speed up and slow down. It's only a limitation if you let it be. (But I will echo @SoundsLikeJoe and @Ross Fortune , sometimes the only way is without a click. Whatever serves the song best)

I've always loved Vulfpeck's approach. For the first few albums every single tracking take was filmed on an iPhone while they recorded in their living room/bedroom/etc, which allowed Jack Stratton to turn around and release low budget music videos for every single song on the album using the take that made the album.

Their setup was always lo-fi and charmingly janky in the edit. They just leaned into the artifice of a low-grade camera and built their whole visual style around these simple phone captures of the session.

    •    Or using offline, on-device alternatives instead

author: Gabriel Tyranny
Rollmottle
content: As others have said, recreating a beat you like is the school you need to go to. One of my favorite beats of all time is Fleetwood Mac's "Hypnotized" which is a swingy, triplet unchanging thing that is effectively a drum loop through the song, except Mick Fleetwood plays it. I recreated it using a sample pack of Mick Fleetwood's and turned it into a song after serious finagling, especially in the context of grid music. The insight into accent, velocity, swing, where in the grid things hit (or don't), which specific hits matter and how dropping just one or two key hits in a repetitive pattern can shift the groove entirely. It also tests your chops for figuring out choke groups, how to make closed and open hi hats sound "real" (if that's your goal) so on and so forth. I also love recreating a beat as a way in when musical inspiration may be lacking.

author: bobby k
content: I think spending your own money to cover someone else’s ass is a slippery slope. Unless you’re in a band, the songs you’re producing aren’t your own (despite how much they feel like they could be). If every artist OP works with hired a shitty mixer for the next 5 years and the only solution he had in mind was to to pay out of pocket, that’s a lot of money he’s losing that could be invested in his own tools and life. This is why I would advocate for a creative problem solving compromise of sorts - find ways to wrap it for free or cheap that don’t suck, or convince the artist to budget better, or learn how to finish out your vision yourself from the rough mixes.

author: Zach Hughes
content: I agree with the slippery slope framing and would advocate for being strategic about how you allocate your resources. But to play devil's advocate, if the OP's future work is hypothetically being mixed by a shitty mixer then he's probably not going to get 5 more years of work as a producer. If the OP invests strategically in great songs and great productions he's probably going to get more work. And that work is likely going to trend towards being with the type of artists who don't hire shitty mixers to mix their records. We tend to compartmentalize our roles but I'm skeptical any future client or the market in general is going to be as discerning. *Who* wants to hire the producer who made the record that sounds 'bad'?

author: samvalentine
Keegan
content: Hey, what do **you **consider to be the difference between a song with 'good' production vs. one with 'bad' production? Recently I realized that the term "production" gets used in a lot of different ways. I used to think everybody meant more or the less what I consider production to be: the recording or engineering of the sounds in the song (so, sound design too), the layering or vertical arrangement of instruments and sounds, and (to a lesser degree) the way those sounds are balanced/mixed to fit together. What made me reconsider this definition was hearing a handful of reviews for the new Charli XCX album criticize the "production" on songs like this one:

author: sukhuno
content: Imo production is all of the choices made before the song goes to the mixer - so all of the instrumentation, arrangement, sound design, etc. I personally wouldn’t expect a mixer to make those choices, simply to enhance the ones that are there already.

author: Rollmottle
content:
I think this is where it starts getting tricky and starts to dip into territory @Zakhiggins was touching on. Is there an objective measure of what good production is? 

Tons and tons of dub and reggae from the 70s and 80s would be what I would consider not necessarily great production -- from a technical standpoint -- but a lot of those shortcomings (noise, grit, distortion, etc.) don't get in the way of the end product because the sum total well surpasses any production shortcomings. Most of the punk, post-punk and hardcore stuff I listened to in the 90s would also fall well below a bar most would consider “well produced” but the music transcends any of that for me. 

So…by my measure, all of these recordings I mentioned ARE well-produced by nature of them being good to me and still “adding up” so to speak. By somebody else's measure, they may not be because they don’t meet some threshold -- be it technical, artistic, whatever -- of what they consider well-produced.

author: ehutton21
content:
Vocalign is really essential to my work flow because of how many harmonies i get from clients & collaborators. I also create doubles with it a lot & use melodyne/alterboy to enhance the texture. 

As far as editing groove/timing, that’s hard cause I always cut that stuff until it feels right. Most of the time I’m gettin tracks where the artist or the producer or whoever (lots of times it’s the same person) has already agonized over the timing and cut it up so it’s solid. I’m mindful of words where the first syllable is cacophony or plosive-based (k, t, d) when it comes to sounds that hit on the quarter note (esp with snares). I usually let those sounds start just before the transient and end so that vowel is starting right on the note, depending on how it’s quantized if that makes sense. 

Feel like groove editing gets a weird wrap but i here songs where the timing could have used aligning after the amount of compression that got applied.

author: cy (sigh)
content:
yeah its very case by case. as far as groove in relation to other elements. I've had guitars recorded loosely toa click and worked the groove around that - lining up the downbeats of the drums/bass  with the guitars even if it's a bit early or late. that was for a more indie type of joint. and for something more trap /modern hip hop, I've nudged bass notes or samples to get them to either sync w drums up for impact  or nudge slightly off to hype of of pull back the energy in the groove. 

as far as programming. I'll play with forward swing and dragging notes a lot if I'm going for a more real/dynamic feel when programming. keeping in mind that if the goal is trying to stay "on time" any fwd swing that might happen at the start of a phrase will be compensated with some drag  after or vice versa.  keeping velocities in mind w drum hits + linking it to a filter env so that harder hits have more high end and softer hits end up a bit rounder.

adding subtle layers that are similar   to the main drums but occupy a different texture or tone  in dif  sections to thicken up the groove or automate the attack /sustain of certain elements thru diff sections to help shift the listener  focus throughout

author: Eric Martin
content: I take off all bus processing and usually eliminate some of the “ear candy” type of processing when I’m making tracks for live, once I’ve got each song I bring them into a new session and balance them against themselves so that loud songs sound loud and quiet songs sound quiet but not drastically different but I don’t add compression or limiting because those things are usually done at front of house and as expressed by others songs hit harder with a live system when they’re more dynamic

author: Slow Hand
content:
(Ok. Now I'm starting to run with this train of thought. Now would be a good time to step off if you've gotten what you need.)

I don't want this to sound like the end-all be-all. One of my absolute favorites is James Brown, and there is no way that some of his songs would hold up to the level of scrutiny I'm describing. And those records *kill*. It's all vibe. It's vibe all the way down, bebe. Not a chord change in sight. Barely a melody in some cases. And that's alright.

So what did James do? More often than not James would get all of his band (real jazz killers) in the studio and he would sing the parts to them one by one and allow them to input their own feel.

He'd start with the drummer and have them play a pattern that James was feeling. Once the drummer was jamming on that he would move on to the bass player and sing them an idea. Once the bass player had that germ of an idea they would continue to jam on it with the drummer, refining and adding their own thing. Then James would move on to the horns, and so on, and so on.

While James could be dictatorial and (from the perspective of music education) the least technically qualified person in the room he had *vision*. 

If the song has a strong identity you can give your players a good (non-technical) prompt and they can interpret that through their own sensibilities. You can describe a mood, or a scene, or an abstract sensation.

R. Kelly once said (I'm paraphrasing): "RnB is supposed to feel like the best moment of your *life*." That simple description conveys so much about the feel, the pleasure, and the joy that he is looking for in his music. It also excludes a lot of possibilities as well. If you can give your players a prompt like *that* then you can get everyone aligned on the same wavelength and it will carry you so much further without the need to dictate parts.

----

author: NoahNeedleman
content:
I’d argue that not all songs with a narrower style or that are more genre specific are necessarily “lesser” songs. The style or genre of the song often informs the parts that are written or played in the studio. 

That being said, it does take a great song to be able to cross multiple genres and still be compelling… just that’s not the only rubric for a great song IMO. 

Now that I’m done with the pedantry, the rest of this manifesto was, per your usual, very well thought out and explained.

author: Zach Hughes
content: I totally agree. The interpersonal relationships with session musicians can impact the project in a huge way. In the case I mentioned I had never met any of the musicians. They were brought in by the artist. However I knew they were all incredible players and I was familiar with their work.

author: Zach Hughes
content: I think it’s a question of trade offs and the pitfalls and benefits of varying choices. I don’t have a specific question but am more curious to discuss the topic  and hear other folks experience. Could go many diff directions.. how do we facilitate those ‘special’ moments with session players? Which I like the idea of getting the piece you know you want or need first and then playing the rest of the time. Or how to communicate and prevent really good players from over powering a song and doing too much? For this project I chose to leave a lot of room for the players to play and write their own parts, but I also needed to reel them in a little bit and simplify what was happening. Even then when I dug through the tracks I had to mute certain fills, take a simpler pass of the keys to let the bass do it’s thing or vice versa. This also makes me consider the question: when do you let a song suggest to you when something special needs to happen?

author: Zach Hughes
content: This is definitely a big piece of the puzzle to me. The last project I worked on before the one I mentioned just above was with an artist who had no vision and deferred to me on almost every choice. My ‘demo’ for the most part became the record with very little outside collaboration not necessarily by my choice but by outside constraints from the artist (I.e. budget and time). I will say the song turned out killer and we both were happy with it but certain avenues were for sure closed along the way that maybe would have served the song more. The project I mentioned in the initial post here was flipped. The artist has a vision and wants to co-produce the record and the ‘demo’ was the most naked version of the song. I think now the contrast of those two projects is why I’m ruminating on all this 🧐

content: So this is the kick drum: I've set the frequency to the root note of the key the song is in (in this case C), low feedback so that it just adds a *hint* of tone, low pass filter, and then I'm using the envelope to control the dry/wet so the attack of the unfiltered sample happens before the tone comes in to avoid messing with the transient - these are for drums, after all

author: hank01564
content: Wow, this is a dream come true on so many levels. I’ve been waiting for an opportunity to have someone listen to my Antares complaints! Third, the default in AAX I remember was the craziest setting. I forget exactly what it was but I remember spending 20 minutes just trying to get it to tune and relearn where everything was. My last  biggest issue is that I’m pretty sure Code Meter (Antares iLok substitute) kicks Dante in the balls every time it wants to check my license. This means late packets on my DVS and in extreme circumstances, drop outs. Autotune doesn’t even have to be in the session for this to happen. This is a hard issue to prove so I’m still a little unsure if I’m right about this one but after uninstalling everything Antares, this problem went away. author: popaganda.
content: One other angle…..if everyone’s not super-stoked on the song where it’s at then it’s probably not done, especially if the artist is one of those people. It may get over-produced, topline written, and then not reduced but completely overhauled and replaced by a new instrumental. Maybe that new instrumental is so dope that you realize topline 1 wasn’t good enough and a whole new melody/lyric gets written. You may strike new gold, you may backtrack, or you may repeat this process again.

author: spectrummasters
content: With regards to making a call , I’d be interested in peoples perspectives . How do you make the call between following an artists ideas and helping them to articulate those ideas vs following your own instincts  that it’s time to move the process on and finish adding ideas in order to resolve and complete ? Ie . Recently I completed a project to master with an artist who was over the moon , planning the video ….no complaints , pure buzz , a few weeks later . I get the message “hey man I was just thinking what if we try and add a piano part “ . Imo the song doesn’t demand it , I suspect friends and armchair mozarts have thrown in their own 2 pence in the last few weeks and now what was in all our opinions 🔥, has to face tinkering . I don’t like telling people what to think , ie . I think you’re making a mistake …..but I don’t like overwriting songs , so for me it’s a obvious f that idea let’s just write another one  . I’d be interested in others internal dialogue with regards to when / if/ how you say no ….and if it sits with you alright personally or you find it problematic (and I ask this in order to find charming but assertive ways to keep the door closed on a project when it truly felt  finished to all involved  and went to full completion / master and release strategy and now as the producer you truly believe it can only be damaged by changes )

author: NoahNeedleman
content: It’s always a tough spot, and artists/clients go one of two ways: endless tinkering or afraid to let you keep adding cause it’s already great. It’s all about building trust between you and trust in the process.

author: spectrummasters
content: Thank you ruairi for your thoughts . V helpful and pertinent. I agree with you very much (at my own current level ) with regards to what mastering means, I agree it should feel like a sacred moment for everyone . Stepping away from the work and letting it take on its own life in the world , not continually calling it back for “what ifs and afterthoughts “ until the moment it was , is lost ...and now its not the capture and articulation of those days in the studio....but musical ponderings attached to those studio moments . But how to articulate this to a young artist who hasn’t been through this passage yet can be tricky. In my culture , here in south London we are v careful to never tell each other what to think or to “correct” one another , it’s felt as a disrespect and respect is all in my circles.....I don’t disagree with it, but it makes it very hard to create “teachable moments “ . The ideas I’ve received from you and Noah are both genuinely applicable and helpful though in exactly this conundrum and I feel a little lighter already . “Weighting “:is a great concept to consider . Thank you

author: Slow Hand
content:
I think the band Secret Chiefs 3 is a good glimpse at what a truly pan-musical approach could be like. Though they are far from pop music. 

They're drawing on a wide variety of musical systems: Western diatonicism, Messiaen-ic (lol) scales, Azerbaijani mugham, Afghani traditionals, Italian avant-garde film score, surf rock, and so on.

They integrate a lot of different tuning systems and rhythmic approaches into their compositions. Trey Spruance has said on a few occasions that their seemingly arabic-sounding music would sound just as foreign to an arab musician as it would to an American listener. They embody a real ethos to fuse as much of these musics together.

https://open.spotify.com/track/2qHkwrDOfg291jbrQbb91z?si=dd5397e501784b3a

Modern R&B and Hip Hop being closely linked together, same with Female R&B artist’s stereotypical toxic relationship songs are also its own box that I can’t seem to avoid wherever I go. R&B at least seem to have more diversity in the type of stories that become heard, hip hop is a lot less like that. 

There are tons of talented women rappers not in that box, but they don’t make it as big nor do people care as much. Kind of frustrating how uniform it has become… But I don’t agree that it’s dead. It’s dead to me, or to you- but it’s still pretty much what people wanna hear all day long.

This sounds juvenile, but I would love for someone to physically model an ass that can fart. Model an airflow with variable air pressure and then an aperture to constrict that flow and a pair of cheeks that flap open and shut several times a second. author: austenballard
content:
I have been on both sides of this situation

One example was that the producer had ghosted the artist, so I redid the instrumental note for note, matching synth patches and everything. Artist decided not to credit the original producer. He got mad and threatened to sue but the legal fees would probably be more than any royalties he made, so that all fizzled out

Another example was that the artist found someone who could finish the project plus mix and master it for less than they would have had to pay me for the final arrangement deliverables. At least I got my 50% down payment.

author: cian riordan
content: I think you've got a real point when you say we've evolved a bit in the 30 years or so since the making of this record. But for one, Bob Rock got an incredible solo out of Kirk and that song and record went on to become an enormous success. I also feel that this particular genre of music was born out of toxic masculinity... and might have been the only positive outcome of it. Coming into the present, I don't think we should treat artists in the studio this way anymore, but then again, we're not really making cock-rock records like this either... the genre has sort of fizzled out naturally.

author: cian riordan
content: There are times when I've been in the studio for months and months with artists and have built a real relationship with (in and out of the studio) that I would feel comfortable pushing like this. But modern record making happens much faster, and much more ad-hoc, so it's very unlikely you could build this kind of trust that quickly.

author: Matthew The Cooke🎄🎅🏻
content: This is exactly why I‘m trying so hard to get the best out of ppl without being an asshole. I had this experience  working with this singer and a songwriter, and the songwriter was extremely dismissive of ideas that weren‘t her own, took things way to personally, was extremely pushy with her ideas, walked out the session for half an hour to take a phone call and generally was very unpleasant to be around. After the session I had to lift up the artist who asked me „is it always like this?“ so I had to reassure them that, no, it‘s not always like this. author: Deleted User
content:
it’s generally the orange if it’s something like palm muted guitars. But always listen and feel it. It can feel better to be early in certain styles but it can feel better to be late on other styles. it also depends on who else is doing what

But groove template is always there if you wanna line it up with other instruments. bounce and make the source and destination audio files the same length, make sure the markers are in the correct place then sync them up. 

I’m 90% manual editing though. Because aligning automatically can fix notes I didn’t want to fix. you can also go measure by measure to be more careful if you want to auto align with groove templates 

you want to ask yourself “is this note late or early?” before making any moves. I like nudging with keyboard so I can fine tune how far it goes. 

Nowadays I’m more committed to “the only way to make the groove feel good is to play it that way”. I hate having to edit and to be honest, nothing beats well played rhythm section… Especially because I do a lot of in between the groove stuff, 30% quantization can mess with the feel of well landed notes. So I’m doing a lot of metronome practice these days

author: Josh
content: The old sturgis way is to make sure the pick attack is before, depending on genre though I’ll often have the pick attack on the beat. Remember when we were doing drums and we just sort of listened to how we it should placed when the drummer flammed the kick and snare? This is the same thing.

author: Rob Domos
content: To be embarrassingly transparent, a lot of times I think a note is late by listening and then after looking find out it was early. Things just feel in time or out. Also, a lot of things that have loose rhythm in a way that people tend to love often bother me and sound out of time to me. Jay-Z is a perfect example of this. I spent years thinking his rhythm was terrible before I realized he was doing a shuffle time feel where the amount his vocal is off from the snare creates the shuffle. I just didn’t pick up on that for like… 15 years? And just wondered why nobody else was bothered him being “out of time”. Kind of like when people with an undeveloped sense of harmony think of jazz as simply being an excuse for allowing wrong notes. That’s how I hear people that are famous for stretching rhythm

author: Deleted User
content:
makes me wonder if you were hearing other instrument that was on the grid - which was later the other instrument that is early, which led to a confusion of perceiving that the other instrument is late. 

also regarding the off-the-grid feel, listening isn’t to james brown or j-dilla isn’t going to do that for you. only playing along to it will get you used to the feel of pushing and pulling thing back and forward. 

but the fundamental is always on the grid stuff. I was in a huge J-Dilla phase for a while and I would try basically play things off for the feels. But it would sound like a mistake as opposed to intentional feel. and that was because I haven’t really mastered being right on the grid yet. I’m still working on being right on the grid by playing with metronome, and I found that actually improved my feel for all kinds of styles of groove. I still need to work on it, but it’s definitely better than before and I need less takes now. 

I know your question was about editing but I think there’s no better way to improve the sense of time and feel than to grab instruments and learn being what on time/late or early feels like.

author: cy (sigh)
content:
see I think my heritage saved my ass on this aspect. catching rhythm is one thing I pride myself in -I'm nowhere near other ppl I  know. but  in high-school when a teacher couldn't manage a class everyone would breakdown into rara /rasin (haitian roots/carnival  music) and start freeatyking insults/jokes about them. everyone would pick a subdivision of the rhythm and play and almost no one was ever out of time. for the most part I can catch complex  rhythms and play to them even if I can't actually count them properly. 

studying non standard tracks might be a good idea @Rob Domos 

https://youtube.com/playlist?list=RDEM98p-nAErqVvow4rwmEtPKg&playnext=1&si=ifw8q5y2iYHfaRjg

TiRoro is a rhythm legend back in Haiti and multiple American jazz drummers came to Haiti to study under him and learn rara, rasin and vodou rhythms

author: cy (sigh)
content:
yup. a lot of blends of regional  African grooves and some indigenous stuff from tainos/arawaks (though those are more present in vodou rhythms) 
I'm always coming back to those things  whether it's to study or take inspiration

author: Deleted User
content:
For sure. Even the greatest session musicians I grew up listening to don’t play it technically at all times. But the first vibey take is gonna be better as I get my chops up. 

In my definition, one take musician still applies as long as I don’t NEED to record another take after the first one. if the first take doesn’t have anything that throws the listener off from feeling the music, that’s as good as I want to be. I’m not crazy about not needing punch ins or comps. 

@popaganda. that’s where Ruairi’s listen like a 15yo girl probably comes in. I’m often listening as myself, I don’t know how to listen outside of my own self. 

Larry Klein said “I usually don’t play bass on my records because it makes me listen as a bassist”. Perspective is everything, and it really can’t be faked or bought. Posing a question to myself to open up to different perspectives is huge

author: Deleted User
content:
The reason why I started obsessing about this is after  I did a live-record-songwriting with an artist. 

I loved everything about the process, but I could feel the artist starting to tumble whenever I’d do something off. What I want is to be good enough so that when there is a special moment, I can live with it without being “I wish someone else played here” or “I wish I didn’t fuck up there, because I stopped the melody or phrase being completed on the spot”

author: Deleted User
content:
But I do want to clarify about my one take musician thing… 

I may have used the term too loosely. To me, most jazz musicians are one take players. They record everything together and calls it. (of course they do a few takes but I’m not trying to be a “first take and that’s it” player)

Being able to play through the whole song (unless arrangement calls for section by section) and just needing to punch in a few spots is what I want. I do not have any desires to go beyond that. 

BUT

I don’t ever want to edit my timing other than micro adjustments that can be done by moving small part of audio clip or hitting quantize. 

That + being more consistent with touch so I don’t have to punch in as much

author: Deleted User
content:
re: 1 

I have gotten over the whole “perfectionism” thing. I still overthink all the time but I can confidently day I am free of perfectionism. I have no problem letting go when it calls for it. I believe there’s a difference between wanting to be better and working towards it vs not being able to move on out of fear and holding onto something without knowing the next move. If that was the case I wouldn’t have sent what I first recorded to the artist. I may have wasted some time thinking I would be able to get this part down, but I don’t think I was being a perfectionist by doing that. 

re: 2

Why would he do this if he’s a great guitarist? Is it a workflow preference or the aesthetic of edit/sampling? I can only imagine it being faster playing the parts in rather than stitching bits together. 



The whole goal is to be able to consistently reproduce that magical groove, and being able to create great moments when I am with other people. I really believe I have a good sense of groove but can’t execute it just yet. 

I can see myself spending countless hours editing myself. (Which I already do daily). That time is better spent working on my chops. If I can hire other musicians so I can stop wasting time trying multiple takes, I would. But I don’t have that just yet. I go by sections or measures most of the time, I don’t just sit there trying to nail ONE perfect take.

author: spectrummasters
content:
Because it’s an open and minimal drum production listen to Calvin harris and the disciples how deep is your love 

In this house style you want to really experiment with note velocities and swing settings (how far you push the swing ) to get it spinning. U.K. producers wrote early house and garage with the grid on 1/24 (triplets ) for the snares and hats . So we are talking take your swing potentially all the way to triplet time  . 

Kick is to have subtle little syncopations and doubles to push the groove (before transitions/ on turnarounds  for example )

author: Deleted User

Art is subjective, so there’s actually no “better” — This is something I need to remind myself of more. The amount of times that I showed something that I thought was good and was rejected, and the times I showed something I hated and got good reactions from  people. You really never know! 

I’ve been doing more writing sessions these days (once or twice a week or so), and I’m really falling in love with this because I can get out of my own head and look around to get a sense of whether an idea is working or not outside of my own opinions

Speaking of the relentless will to finish: would it be a producer’s job to stay on top of getting others in team to get their parts done? If I’ve done my part already and completed it, do I keep bothering them to get their parts done? (lyrics etc) 

I read your reply to someone asking about writing sessions, and you said your biggest goal is to get the vocals from the first spark of inspiration on that same day. I’ve had sessions where I get a basic bone of ideas with beat done, and top line is done but the lyrics are recorded in Gibberish and stream of consciousness. I would return, complete the arrangement on my own - send it back, they said they fuck with it and tells me they will finish the lyrics. How long do I wait, do I follow up at all, or do I just move on and keep making more? I don’t want to overstep or rush people (and.. I can’t get anyone to anything of course), but I also want to get the song done while I’m excited so I can keep moving forward. It’s hard to tell if I can even do about it or if I should just keep it moving and leave it be

author: popaganda.
content: I’ll try to summarize: the artist and the audience are like 2 people in a relationship. 1st album: you meet and there’s a curiosity and charm. 2nd album you’re really getting to know them and you like each other. 3rd album: they do or say something that pisses you off. They challenge you. You fight and argue but you still stuck with them. The relationship grows from there etc. but if the artist ever takes their gaze away from their fanbase they lose them. All trust is eroded. It’s like being at a party talking to someone and they glance around for a split second looking for someone cooler to schmooze with. It’s offensive and heartbreaking when that happens

author: louisvie
content:
Hi everyone, here's the situation for me right now 

Singer/Artist/Band Leader wants to release big single with video in 4 days to coincide with band's concert. (In important small venue in Paris, FR (hometown) friends will be there, big event he rightly envisions as a celebration for the new kick-ass song with the new kick-ass video.)

But, as close friend, band-in-question-member, sound guy and producer for the project, I think we should wait and take time to get very good vocals, while right now it feels like they're merely existing because song has to have vocals. Leaves no strong impression, or the impression that the performance lacks intention.

Band rocks (his guitar included), Harmonies and Gang Vocals are cool. 
Really the lead vocal is the only thing in the way of getting the song to be really good. 

On the one hand, I feel like his intuition for the release date (deadline is in 4 days) is good and could be very valuable for us.
On the other, I don't see why anyone would be truly excited for us if singer is mid.
(I know he's good deep down, he's given me chills when singing with no pressure, rn we're just lacking some of that magic.)

As the song is today, you wouldn't love to listen to the song on your way to work or school, enjoying it for what it is.

Anyway, right now I'm going to try and squeeze that magic out of him in the next following days when we can see each other.
As I'm typing this I also realize I should send him the instrumental and let him try shit alone. 

Maybe that's my answer.

author: markmaclure
content:
Anyone have any tips on working with new artists/producers with no filter? Like where they NEED to try out every idea they have, even if it's not good, or if it's a bad time (ie we're tracking guitars and they stop everyone to try out a (bad) bass idea). 

I'm on a project right now where a new artist is bringing their songwriting partner to every session as a producer. This is their first production gig (which is fine), but we're wasting a lot of time on ideas that get scrapped later on. This person has a good ear, and occasionally has GREAT ideas, but it takes forever for them to let go of bad ideas. 

It takes all of my patience to very slowly walk them through why the ideas aren't working, and there's a lot of pushback when I do. A lot of "but can we just try it? I really feel like it will work" then 3 hours later "oh yeah I think you were right let's delete it".

author: Maxim
content: To make things a bit bigger, Shopify makes almost 3 billion in revenue every year, yet the companies built on top of Shopify make close to 200 billion combined. The company that makes 100 million a year using Shopify doesn't pay that much more than the company that only makes 100k a year. What I mean by that, Oliver created a sample pack that thousands of people can use the way they want to. Why should they by default get credit when someone comes along and builds something that's widely successful with that? Didn't everyone win? (Of course it's not the same but I'm trying to get to the source which is I think what we believe to be artistic integrity).

author: Bryan DiMaio

author: Bryan DiMaio
content:
You and many other musicians are a different type of listener to the general public, where they put on a song because they like the end product and have no idea about the creation. One isn’t necessarily less valuable than the other.
One could make the argument for sampling popular music as a way to include the listener in the homage the creator of the sampled product is paying to the original art. It can call back to a nostalgic time and help inform the context of the new form. Art is always changing and evolving and I’m sure this same discussion was had at the advent of MIDI, sampling, the printing press, etc

author: Bryan DiMaio

author: Eric Martin
content:
As an artist, I bounce my own stems and basically route things for what I want the show to be, sometimes all vocal FX and BGV’s get routed to one stem and the only thing I leave out is the actual lead that will be sung live, and then I’ll even bounce some drum FX out so that the live drums are supported with some of the FX that were used on the record.

LIVE production and STEMS for publishing are two different things from an artist perspective IMO

author: chris_donlin
content: Need some advice here! I've been working with an artist for a little over a year, have made 8 or 9 songs. We've had to retrack vocals for nearly every song because the performance just isn't quite there yet, but we always get it where we want it in the second session. I'm noticing a pattern of him sitting with the vocal and realizing he wants to sing it differently/better, but only feels this after we've tracked it once. Today was day 1 tracking vocals on a new song and it got to the point where i realized we were going to have to try again another day, I was felt fed up. I tried to discern what exactly i was frustrated at. Part of me was frustrated because it doesnt seem like he is ever truly prepared to track vocals, in the sense of being warmed up, having ideas of how he wants to sing, practicing ahead of time, singing random stuff in between takes, etc. The other part of me was frustrated with myself because im aware some of the responsibility falls on me as the producer/coach. I have no problem taking time to edit the vocal, i know it's part of the job, i enjoy it in fact haha - but is it fair to have certain expectations from him as the artist? I want to have a conversation with him about it but also be clear that i want to be better at my job too

author: chris_donlin
content: Appreciate the reassurance. I will agree with what you said about knowing what the artist needs to be happy, i forget how far that goes

author: EliHeathMusic
content: I've definitely experienced similar frustration in the past working with singers coming in unprepared. While there are always ways for us to improve as vocal producers and editors at the end of the day a really good comp of a bad performance isn't going to be as compelling as a good performance (maybe there are some exceptions). It sounds like you've been getting good performances the second time around so maybe that's all that matters but it might be worth having a conversation about how the artist can come in better prepared in the future (sharing practice strategies rather than scolding).

author: Josh
content: Honestly dude think of this like any other relationship you have. I stopped working with an artist I was close with because he never even wrote anything. He wanted me to do everything short of actually singing it, and then he was hard to get a half decent vocal out of. Because I felt like I was barely even making art at some point, I just stopped booking with him and he just hit me up last week saying he’s trying to write on his own again. Odd perspective, but I think I was too helpful and because he was insecure about his thoughts, ideas, and abilities, he ended up using me as a crutch, which is partly my fault. In the end, me moving on made him want to write again and I think that’s a super positive outcome considering I had a lot of negative feelings about it at the beginning of the year

author: Josh
content: Now I want to hear what’s he’s writing and get back to working with him because now I have something that isn’t mine to work with. Our best song together was our first song, which he completely wrote on his own and I feel like I only watered down his voice from that point on as he started writing less.

author: bobby k

Open-ended question i would love to pick your lovely brains on — 

I’ve started working with an artist who’s caught some good momentum doing the selfie singer songwriter thing on social media. It’s just acoustic guitar + vocals on an iPhone video. author: Slow Hand
content:
Other strategies for re-vamping the feel and arrangement:
1. Trying putting instruments in different registers (move the bass up/down an octave).
2. Play the song in a neutral form like only piano and vocals and listen for what it might suggest.
3. Substitute instruments (Ex: bowed bass instead of electric bass).
4. Try a different key.
5. Try half-time. Try double-time.

author: Deleted User
content:
I want to chime in here, I mostly agree with what the others said and as long as you don’t unintentionally clip all is well. But I think we can dig a bit deeper.

I like to work in a way during tracking/production that’s maybe a bit more old school with shooting for around -18dbFS on the average. It gives me a kind of fixed reference in my mind which gives me enough headroom for most dynamics. Now the important part is you have to turn up your monitoring/headphones volume to be adequately loud to work with those lower levels and then leave it there.That being said it might be necessary to bring down other pre existing tracks that are too loud.

Now since the volume of the monitoring/headphones stays the same during that tracking session you can use the gain of your preamp (or the output gain of the compressor, if you’re using one on the way in) to adjust the vocal or instrument so that for every part of the arrangement it feels right. So in a sense you are pre mixing during the recording, taking off some work down the line

author: chris_donlin
content: Love this question, I’ve been on a big panning journey the last two months because I’ve always just doubled things and panned everything evenly. I was listening to an episode on Sonic Scoop about Nigel Godrich’s approach to mixing and it was really eye opening to hear how bold his mixes are. I used to get distracted when something was panned but not balanced but after just forcing myself to do it I’ve gotten more comfortable, and even fallen a bit in love with what panning can do. I’ve noticed I have a tendency to pan instruments a certain way, pianos sound better panned, electric guitars always feel better panned right, no reason why it just does. Find what feels good to you! I haven’t gotten bold enough to pan bass and drums to a side. One day

author: Gabriel Tyranny
content:
My current approach to this involves a couple of principles, but this is the first that comes to mind:

1. If there’s a part with bg vocals performing different lines than the lead and there’s a lot going on, I try to have a spot earlier in the song where the exactly lines those BGs are performing have a moment to shine. For example, if there’s a low energy bridge where they can be clearly understood before the big hook where they can be perceived but not understood as well in the midst of so much. 

What this does is allow the listeners brain to process what’s being said with little effort, and then later when it’s in a tornado they can still perceive what it’s saying because they recognize it as something their brain already knows, so it’s not overwhelming for their brain to understand the words of multiple vocals going at once if there are layers of lines being performed (usually syncopated) around each other.

This applies to instruments as well, but instead of intelligibility of words I focus more on cutting frequencies so everything can fit well in the big moments. If they head a synth at full power in the intro and it comes back for a final hook, you can get away with cutting a lot of meat off of it and still have it be perceived as the same synth, without muddying the mix and also creating a nice ‘bringing the song full circle’ feeling - If the track calls for that.

I typed this off the cuff based in gut instinct so not standing by this message as full proof, but this all feels right to me as I explore what I have done for tracks, without having this much thought or words to it.

author: Gabriel Tyranny
content:
To stick with a song I made, MIRROR, I had the lead say anxieties earlier in the song in the middle, then later add those full lines as BGs that almost swirl around the last hooks lead. The lead is performing a part that’s trying to overcome anxieties, and the BGs are saying full lines with the anxieties from before.

Panning was essential to create the effect of the anxieties around the lead, but I found that if I introduced them as panned BGs they were hard to make out behind the lead.

Because of this, knowing when to make a moment earlier in the song to spotlight what would later be panned made those lines more intelligible once they were in the BG to the sides, because the listeners brain recognized it from an earlier section.

Does that make sense? I can struggle to explain what I’m doing in practice and this is my attempt, so my bad if it sounds like gobrish

author: Zack Hames
content:
here's the workflow:

I don't use many of the preset kits anymore. Just not really the sounds I'm looking for. I have a massive library of samples that i like to use. Accessing those is easy.
The problem is I don't make preset kits. Every session, every kit, is a different combination of things, always starting fresh. So I am in the Library view constantly going through samples/files to load into any Cell of Battery.

When I find a sound I like, I can click it or drag it to the cell I want. This is all great.

But, the second i drop it in, I have to change the velocity from 0-100% (I saved my default preset to have all cells at 0% velocity which seems to be working). and then *every time i add a new sample or replace a sample* it makes it a loop in the "Editor" window. There is no shortcut, no preference, no saving a preset, that allows me to essentially remove that behavior.

author: BananErMat42
content:
Bit of a ramble here, guess its a little pushback to commonly seen advice on making music.

Last night i again went at a song ive been working on for an album. I’m three years in by this point and this song is the one that has been the most difficult. Ive made huge rearrangements and changes to this song probably 5-6 times by this point, and always came back to it thinking it still isnt there. The basic concept is alluring but my execution is lacking. 

So most people say "scrap it", if the song doesnt come easy then its not meant to be, and you’re better served making a new track entirely. Maybe integrate the best ideas, but start over. You’re in too deep and you’ll never hear it for what it is by this point.

author: BananErMat42
content: I guess my point is some times great songs take lots and lots and lots of time and trial and error. I think scrapping and moving on is generally good advice, but if your gut is telling you a song will eventually reveal itself, stick to it. If you dont have deadlines looming and it doesnt drive you insane, give it a good few tries, try very different options, and allow yourself to be playful until you maybe find that gold. But i guess that gut feeling of "there’s great in there" has to be fairly strong for this to work. Trust your gut though.

author: oaklandmatt
content:
And not just for making things incrementally better, but for solving problems as well.

I recently was mixing a song with a young mixer who I gave my session to. I heard a very subtle low and thump after two particular downbeat and we could not figure out what it was. We solo'ed some groups and then I remembered that he had replicated my autotune settings on the bass guitar (he had a slightly different version). I know from lots of tuning experience that different modes will occasionally cause different types of artifacts. So we solo'ed the bass, switched from "modern" (his default) to "classic" and it was solved.

author: longstoryshort
content:
one of my earlier experiences writing for other people (ghost producing for a few DJs) in that same kinda lane, future bass ish

i used to produce before i would *write* sometimes, and the energy would just get sucked right out of the room

as soon i opened serum they'd say oh we're not getting a record done today

that moment really hurt me at that time, but later on i realized it was true - it's always the true criticism that really hits, right?

so i made adjustments by building out my sounds/library/synth patches in advance, so when sessions came up i would be able to just fire in 90% of the way done sounds.

when the song was written then i'd finish up the sounds and do the tweaking and the session had so much momentum it didn't take long to finish.

records got done, money was made, everyone was happier.

author: Will Trotman
content:
What are y’all’s philosophies on sending in progress bounces to artists?

I almost always feel that it’s harmful to the process on all sides. To varying degrees, depending on the artist. I would love to say I don’t send anything before a legit “Mix 1,” but I feel hesitant to make a hard rule around it for some reason. So when I’m asked for one, I usually just say something along the lines of “I strongly recommend not taking bounces home with you for XYZ reasons, but if you really want one I’ll send it over” lol.

author: oaklandmatt
content: Often times the compromise for day-of bounces is letting me listen fresh the next morning so I can make a few balance adjustments

author: Will Trotman
content:
Hahaha the bounce stand off is real. I’ll probably try harder to enforce it as a rule from now on. 

I’m always amazed how much it benefits songs I’m writing or my productions when I only have the version in my head when I’m away from the studio. I feel like I remember the song how it *should* be and not in its rough draft form, if that makes sense. Seems like ideas often self correct when they live in your head and stay malleable.

author: austenballard
content:
What about when _many_ tasks become easy, thereby clearing the path to do even harder things?

All the art we make now - music, film/tv, video games... all possible because lots of subordinate tasks became easier. 

I firmly subscribe to Wagner's concept of Gesamtkunstwerk (Total Artwork), my take on which is that as art forms become easier to do, they are subordinated to even greater, more total art forms

The example I like to use is a videogame. Making a AAA game needs writers, artists, composers, actors, programmers.... video games are (I think?) by far the largest form of cultural output in economic terms because they're so encompassing of so many human skills

Now that those human skills are getting easier with AI assistance, what's next? How does art, culture, entertainment become even _bigger_, what does our next great format of cultural output look like?

Went a little off-topic for this channel but I am constantly thinking about this
